description: Chan Marshall's new album comes 17 years after her debut as Cat Power and six years after her most recent collection of original material. Sun, her first album to feature synthesizers, Auto-Tune, and Iggy Pop, exists completely and defiantly outside of any larger musical trends.

title: The Bloom and the Blight
label: ATO
description: The duo return with a new album that roughs up rustic folk with shameless metal riffing, a mix that at times recalls the Zep boom of the White Stripes or the boogie doom of Dax Riggs.

title: The Orbserver in the Star House
label: Cooking Vinyl
description: Rather than embalming their past glories or forcing a big statement, the Orb sound like they're having fun on these jams, recorded quickly in Berlin, with dub pioneer Lee "Scratch" Perry.

title: The North
label: ATO
description: The Canadian band's sixth album proves a return to form after the disappointing run of recent years. The North conjures the ghosts of past glories without sounding forced, unspooling pleasantly and unhurriedly.

title: Breakup Song
label: Polyvinyl
description: Whilst recent Deerhoof albums have occasionally tilted toward sonic exhaustion, Breakup Song is a nice swing in the other direction. It's a quick, pithy album, with 11 songs lasting just 30 minutes.

title: Centipede Hz
label: Domino
description: Following their critical and commercial breakthrough, 2009's Merriweather Post Pavilion, Animal Collective return with a dense and busy album that serves as the more anxious flipside to its blissed-out predecessor.

title: Verdonkermaan
label: Hydra Head
description: On their latest album, the relentlessly savage Dutch black metal band completes the trilogy it started with its first release, 2007's Krach. They've hit their stride with this gleefully abrasive offering.

title: Serpentine Path
label: Relapse
description: Featuring the entirety of Brooklyn-via-Long Island doom trio Unearthly Trance along with Tim Bagshaw of UK stoner/psych heavyweights Ramesses and Electric Wizard, Serpentine Path offer a blend of extreme doom and death metal on this admirably streamlined debut LP.

title: Django Django
label: Because
description: Blending prairie guitars and chirruping synthesizes, the Edinburgh psychedelic band's eponymous debut is rendered in two basic colors (natural and synthetic), but the scenarios it conjures are significantly more multifaceted.

title: Düde
label: Tin Angel
description: Xiu Xiu's Jamie Stewart and Angela Seo team with Italian weird-rock shifters Larsen for a third XXL collection. The band originally improvised these pieces, rearranged them, and then quickly put down the definite versions found here.

title: I Get Wet
label: Century Media
description: Ten years on, Andrew W.K.'s album-length party is still raging, and it's been fleshed out with a deluxe reissue that includes live cuts and demos. Whether you consider these songs to be brilliant, brilliantly dumb, or just flat-out dumb, they have lost none of their utility.

title: Sagittarian Domain
label: Editions Mego
description: Oren Ambarchi had one day in the studio to complete Sagittarian Domain. The album, which consists of one 33-minute track featuring the Australian musician and a three-piece string section, is a gigantic standoff between restriction and freedom.

title: Respect the Fly Shit
label: Greedhead / LRG
description: Meyhem Lauren's new free mixtape features Action Bronson, Heems, RiFF RAFF, Roc Marciano, Sean Price, and others. Fortunately for Lauren's sake, he gets to outshine some of his peers by default.

title: Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them
label: Fat Beats
description: Originally released as a murky collection on Bandcamp last year, Exile's newly mixed and mastered take on Give Me My Flowers While I Can Still Smell Them imbues the kinetic, syllable-twisting rapper Blu's LP with a sweet, contemplative sound.

title: Lo Fi High Fives... A Kind of Best Of...
label: O Genesis
description: R. Stevie Moore has released 400 or so albums since the late 1960s. Issued by the Charlatans' Tim Burgess, this compilation follows last year's Ariel Pink-curated collection with a focus on Moore's knowing take on pop and his fondness for Ween-style prankster rock.

title: America
label: Domino
description: America is both Dan Deacon's most expansive album and his most inward-looking. The first half's an attempt to extend his range as a songwriter beyond human freak-out. The second half's four linked pieces add up to his most intricate, involving piece to date.

title: Let's Build a Pussy / One Plus One
label: Palilalia
description: During their mid-90s career, Miami's Harry Pussy were described as "just about the most abrasive band America has ever seen." For One Plus One, founding guitarist Bill Orcutt combed through and re-edited over 10 hours of Walkman-recorded sessions. On Let's Build a Pussy, he isolated a second of drummer/singer Adris Hoyo's voice then stretched it.

title: Positive Force
label: Luaka Bop
description: Signed to David Byrne's Luaka Bop label, and responsible for making Yeasayer's Anand Wilder excited about guitar again, the 25-year-old New Jersey musician Steve Marion offers plenty of vivid, lively playing on his latest album as Delicate Steve.

title: Believe You Me
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: A product of nearly two years of casually jamming, Believe You Me is Asthmatic Kitty labelmates Helado Negro and Julianna Barwick's debut record together as OMBRE. It comes off as a collaboration between two dyed-in-the-wool daydreamers.

title: Key to the Kuffs
label: Lex
description: Currently in exile in England, DOOM teams with producer Jneiro Jarel for a collection featuring Damon Albarn and Portishead's Beth Gibbons, among others. The rapper's nothing if not adaptable, and his sense of humor is always present, even when there's good reason to be disillusioned.

title: Pink
label: Text
description: Collecting a year's worth of heady dance singles plus two unreleased tracks, Pink suggests Four Tet is capable of going deeper and expanding higher than almost anyone else out there.

title: Temporary Room
label: Polyvinyl
description: The Bloomington, Ind., duo has the youthful tendency to get canonical with its influences on its debut album-- the Jesus and Mary Chain, Joy Division, Echo and the Bunnymen. With its charmingly monomaniacal focus, Temporary Room hovers like a coal-black cloud on a hot day.

title: Based on a T.R.U. Story
label: Def Jam
description: Once you understand the 2 Chainz persona, there's no narrative, no room for introspection, no flexibility, nothing beyond the one-dimensional caricature he's crafted on countless other verses. Whether he succeeds or fails on his debut LP, then, relies heavily on how funny you think lines such as, "Go so hard, Viagra try to sign me," really are.

title: Years Past Matter
label: self-released
description: Though the fourth and best album by the New York black metal re-constructors Krallice is the band's shortest to date, it is also their most relentless and unforgiving. It's a daunting, rewarding hour that calls for complete immersion.

title: Beams
label: Ghostly
description: Beams again finds the Detroit producer fully inhabiting his ink-black, hedonistic world and extends his run of strong vocal-oriented records.

title: Nocturne
label: Captured Tracks
description: Wild Nothing's second album, Nocturne, distinguishes itself from the crowded pack of dream-pop nostalgists for the same reason 2010's Gemini did-- Jack Tatum is simply one of the best songwriters in this field, and Nocturne's significant upgrade in fidelity makes that point more clearly than ever.

title: Poor Moon
label: Sub Pop
description: The Pac-NW "supergroup" includes members of Fleet Foxes, and it's hard to view them as anything but a side project-- not worthless or redundant but dramatically overshadowed.

title: Steam Days
label: Border Community
description: The producer of pastorlal electronic music returns with an album partway between 2006's effervescent Drowning in a Sea of Love and 2009's rougher-edged Hard Islands.

title: This Time
label: Ruffhouse
description: The troubled rapper, staring down a two-year prison sentence for tax evasion, releases a deeply flawed album that nontheless allows his voice to cut through the static.

title: A Thing Called Divine Fits
label: Merge
description: Britt Daniel of Spoon and Dan Boeckner of Wolf Parade and Handsome Furs come together for a new project that they swear will be ongoing. We should hope so.

title: The Seer
label: Young God
description: Swans are a band that conjure primal forms of power. Their second studio album since re-forming is among the group's longest and it manages to expand on their sound while simultaneously summarizing everything they've recorded before.

title: Enjoy It While It Lasts
label: Fiction
description: Spector's M.O. is to hark back to what he perceives as a halcyon early-2000s time of titting about in indie discos in East London, but the East London five-piece's debut is unmemorable and catastrophically overproduced.

title: Takin' the Time
label: Drag City
description: This Drag City reissue of 1980's Takin' the Time is adventurous and wide-eyed, offering the impression of the young Californian Kleyn discovering her own unique voice and style-- firstly as a harpist, then a singer, and finally a songwriter.

title: Occasion For Song
label: Misra
description: On its latest album, the Ohio band confronts the passing of its violinist Noel Sayre with one of the most incisive and moving mediations on life and loss in recent memory.

title: Life Is People
label: Dead Oceans
description: The cult singer-songwriter's first proper album in 40 years proves that his beloved early recordings were no fluke. Jeff Tweedy guests on this expert singer-songwriter album, which is as dependent upon keen insight as it is upon meticulous arrangement.

title: Mature Themes
label: 4AD
description: Mature Themes is Ariel Pink's grittier, gristlier, and funnier follow-up, an album that clarifies that Before Today was not a sign of things to come but rather just a signpost along his strange journey.

title: How to Live With a Phantom
label: Other Music
description: To begin understanding Shintaro Sakamoto, it helps to start with Todd Rundgren. Sakamoto started his career with a psych-pop garage band before decamping into the studio to make the Platonic ideal of pop music by himself.

title: Hasta La Muerte
label: Southern Lord
description: When this Pomona, Calif.-based band sticks to the conventions and motions of both hardcore and doom, the blend can be exhilarating; at its best, this is a huge-sounding record.

title: Electric Hawaii
label: Fire
description: This New Zealand band's fronted by Kody Nielson, the brother of Unknown Mortal Orchestra's Ruban Nielson. Their dreamy 10-song debut features lightly grooving, lightly melancholic indie pop.

title: Researching the Blues
label: Merge
description: Written and recorded around 2007 after Redd Kross were coaxed out of retirement for a handful of festival dates, Researching the Blues proves the L.A. band still has a knack for shifting power pop into fresh shapes.

title: Parklive
label: EMI
description: Following the recent career-spanning Blur 21 box set, at a moment when the band's legacy is in the process of being revisited, Parklive captures Blur's transcendent and exuberant 25-song set at the Olympic Closing Ceremony Concert in Hyde Park. It's not hard imagining it becoming the band's definitive live release.

title: Big Inner
label: Hometapes / Spacebomb
description: Matthew E. White's debut shares a number of traits with his hero Randy Newman's Good Old Boys: it's southern, definitely other, and full of tales about painfully human creatures yearning for transcendence, and finding that their flawed flesh-and-blood selves get in the way.

title: Sounds of the Syrian Houran
label: Sham Palace
description: This compilation of 1990s-2000s Syrian dabke music, a jittery and buzzing staple of wedding ceremonies, was put together by Sublime Frequencies associate Mark Gergis for his Sham Palace imprint.

title: Mungodelics
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Arriving less than a year after Mungolian Jet Set's official mixed-bag debut, the Norwegian disconauts have put together this assemblage of new tracks, collaborations, and remixes for other artists. Mungodelics can't help seeming corrective, though when what requires correcting is so obvious, it just seems like good sense.

title: Going Blank Again
label: Ride
description: On their 1992 sophomore record, UK shoegazers Ride managed one thing My Blood Valentine never accomplished after Loveless: facing the crippling expectations and making a tremendous follow-up record.

title: Devotion
label: Universal Island
description: The South London singer Jessie Ware is a devout realist making the most of her pop-star dreams. Her commitment to both sides of that equation is what turns her debut album into a uniquely soulful masterclass.

title: Swearin'
label: Salinas
description: The Brooklyn- and Philadelphia-based band's self-titled debut looks beyond pop-punk toward something more distinct and considered. Their scrappy, snarky rock, unshakeable hooks, and genuine lyrics suggest writers who learned a thing or two about melodic punk poetry from Jawbreaker or the Promise Ring.

title: See the World Given to a One Love Entity
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Comprising members of Liturgy, Two Prong, and Eartheater, Guardian Alien's new LP builds one titanic, steady wall of sound over 37 minutes that never shifts dramatically. Instead, it thickens, lightens, surges, subsides; it's mantra music that commands the senses.

title: Afar
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Kurt Feldman's projects over the past five years have mostly looked to the past. His debut solo LP teems with the lush, swooning textures and big-money eccentricities of 80s pop and new-wave-- proving surprising, considering his largely rock-heavy background.

title: Hot Cakes
label: Wind-Up
description: On their first album in seven years, the Darkness trade their singular, self-mocking sleaze for broader, more encouraging sentiments about hanging on to the good times, revealing a slick power-pop band beneath their known love of heavy metal histrionics.

title: Fragrant World
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Yeasayer's third LP is an abrupt transition for a band whose sound always seems to be in flux, bearing both a more limited stylistic range and a narrower sense of identity.

title: Cold of Ages
label: Profound Lore
description: Creating a sound that is distinctly American in execution, the California black metal quintet's members pull together to impart their own distinct sonic sensibilities onto the winding, droning sagas of their excellent second LP.

title: Cid Rim
label: LuckyMe
description: Clemens Bächer, who twiddles knobs as Cid Rim when not collaborating with fellow Austrian beatmaker Dorian Concept, is a free jazz percussionist by trade. His debut for the hip Glasgow-based LuckyMe imprint (Machinedrum, TNGHT) is admirably out of step with his peers.

title: Obama Basedgod
label: self-released
description: As you might expect from a release referencing a United States president, Lil B's latest mixtape Obama Basedgod tackles social ills the only way Lil B knows how: through a free-flowing and meditative lens. It's perhaps his most straightforward, rap-rap offering since 2011's I'm Gay.

title: Melodica
label: Black Mines
description: The re-release of Blackalicious' 1994 debut EP shows it to be conscious-minded, lyrically technical underground hip-hop at its rawest and, sometimes, at its most over-the-top ridiculous.

title: Four
label: Frenchkiss
description: The London band's new record appears to be an exercise in propaganda for their combined health: Alluding to the bond between the band's members and having reached the fourth LP in their catalog, Four feels like revisionist history in action.

title: Enterprising Sidewalks
label: Slumberland
description: The near-forgotten Slumberland Records band release their first album in almost two decades, staving off their early emo leanings and railing against vacuity.

title: Safe Travels
label: Yep Roc
description: Listening to the latest album by the peppy piano-pop Brooklyn trio feels a little bit like stumbling unexpectedly into a Broadway musical at that precise moment when everyone breaks into song.

title: Shake My Head
label: Odessa
description: On its latest album, the obsession-inducing North Carolina garage band integrates the diversity that was found on its first two LPs into a charging, playful collection. Largely recorded in something of a party atmosphere, Shake My Head is a sad-eyed celebration record.

title: Reissues
label: Merge
description: Archers of Loaf always knew that a band has to keep moving, or they'll die. While it's not hard to hear their verve starting to fade a bit throughout this pair of reissues, complete with 4-track demos and B-sides, you can't say they didn't go down swinging.

title: Just Tell Me That You Want Me: Tribute to Fleetwood Mac
label: Hear Music / Concord
description: Randall Poster, music supervisor behind Wes Anderson's films and the 2007 soundtrack to Todd Haynes' Dylan biopic I'm Not There, gathers together Beck, MGMT, the New Pornographers, Best Coast, Washed Out, Lykke Li and more to pay tribute to the Mac.

title: En Yay Sah
artist: Janka Nabay and the Bubu Gang
label: Luaka Bop
description: Driven by civil war from his native Sierra Leone to New York, Janka Nabay joined with members of Skeletons, Chairlift, Highlife, and Saadi to make En Yay Sah, a powerfully modern, cosmopolitan introduction to bubu's complex and vibrant rhythms.

title: Fabriclive 64
label: Playground
description: South-west London DJ Oneman continues his streak for impeccable mixes with his Fabriclive entry. It's witty, visceral, and delights in unspooling bass culture history old and new.

title: Nicole and Natalie
label: self-released
description: Despite their 2004 major-label debut having sold in excess of 300,000 copies, twin sister duo Nina Sky have self-released their two albums since then. The latest sees the genre-embracing duo dabbling in radio-ready Europop, which suits them just fine.

title: Pink Keys
label: Olde English Spelling Bee
description: The Brooklyn label Olde English Spelling Bee springs back into life with underground veteran Alice Cohen's second full-length of 2012: Pink Keys is a collection of crystal visions, palimpsest vocals, and unreliable machinery.

title: Roxy Music: The Complete Studio Recordings 1972-1982
label: Virgin
description: This career-spanning box set to mark Roxy Music's 40th anniversary is often startling, usually wonderful, and more affecting than expected. It's also fascinating as the story of a gradual hardening of an elegant, enigmatic persona, of Bryan Ferry's transformation from art-school pop star to self-made sphinx.

title: Nothing Bad Will Ever Happen
label: Captured Tracks
description: The UK band's first full-length since upgrading to a five-piece recalls the 90s revivalism of recent releases by bands such as Yuck or members of the Woodsist roster.

title: Molecular Genetics from the Gold Standard Labs
label: Anti-
description: It's hard to imagine a more perverse joke than the Locust releasing an album of so-called "obscurities," accessibility hardly being one of their USPs in the first place. Fans of wacko caterwauling and oppressive noise are sure to find Genetics a lo-fi and hideous laugh riot.

title: Raw Money Raps
label: Brainfeeder
description: This L.A.-via-Chicago producer/rapper's debut comes courtesy of Flying Lotus' Brainfeeder imprint. It's a daring release that finds Jae sublimating his voice to the experimentally minded production.

title: Instinct
label: Sub Pop
description: On their long-awaited debut, the Swedish duo flits between the sound of Fleetwood Mac, Prince, Cyndi Lauper, and trashy Europop, while delighting in emotional precipices and tremendous, history-making passions.

title: Anastasis
label: PIAS
description: Dead Can Dance's first new album together in 16 years finds Brendan Perry and Lisa Gerrard in fine form, seamlessly incorporing sounds from around the world. Despite the long layoff, Anastasis is a logical and satisfying progression from the band's mid-90s albums.

label: Earache
description: While Hour of 13's trad black metal imagery proves rather predictable, and their music hardly vanguard, the hard, fast, and fun way in which they perform these songs recharges the genre rather than simply replicating it.

title: Ancient Future
label: Ghostly
description: Ryuichi Sakamoto and Christopher Willits' latest sparse collaboration demonstrates the human impulse to take an unfathomably circuitous route to even get near what should be a straightforward, desired destination.

title: Facedown EP
label: Dirty Hit
description: The Manchester band's debut EP proves unwisely heavy on the torch songs, but their willingness to reveal something about themselves since their anonymously released first single adds welcome background that works in their favor.

title: II
label: Nude Beach
description: The Brooklyn trio's latest record was created with the belief that a trebly guitar riff, a no-bullshit drum beat, and a heart-melting chorus can still rip out the hearts of hopeless romantics young and old.

title: Eraserhead
label: Sacred Bones
description: The soundtrack to David Lynch's surreal 1977 cult film is given a lavish vinyl reissue by Sacred Bones. Thirty-five years later, the gorgeous sound design, built on the rumble and hiss of industry, remains a masterpiece of dark ambiance.

title: Of Babalon
label: Profound Lore
description: Ryan Lipynsky and Tim Call's latest album is their finest to date, consistently and successfully skewing black metal into beguiling new forms-- even though the Howling Wind is not a full-time band for either member.

title: Wavelength
label: De Stijl
description: On Wavelength, Lubelski is still happily tucked into her own shrouded corner, making subtle music that'll click with those for whom Lubelski's understated approach has inherent appeal.

title: Tesco
label: Norman
description: Matthew Herbert reverts to his turn-of-the-millennium moniker for a low-key concept piece about consumerism. Even on a low-stakes project, he still can't help bringing a certain baseline of invention and personality to it.

title: Sod in the Seed
label: Anticon
description: WHY?'s first release in three years finds the band in typically awkward form, but in a way that doesn't appear to be intentional. Weirdly, the EP works best when its tracks feel more like sketches.

title: No Idols
label: Odd Future
description: The latest from the Odd Future member pairs him with producer and Eminem collaborator the Alchemist for a more assured album that focuses on his solid rapping.

title: Maps EP
label: Temporary Residence
description: The San Diego band's second post-comeback release sees them no closer to rediscovering their post-hardcore prowess, making for a jumbled EP that one can only hope turns out to be a palate-cleansing exercise.

title: Forever So
label: Sub Pop
description: Too many breakup albums couch personal matters in universal terms, but Husky Gawenda smartly takes the opposite route on his band's confidently calm debut LP, recounting a past relationship in fits and starts rather than oversharing on the details.

title: Tourist/Sleeper
label: Full Time Hobby
description: Hampshire-born electronic producer James Welch pairs two EPs into one promising release; the mix of djembe drums, bongos, and chimes at its best recalls Everything Ecstatic-era Four Tet.

title: Now Here's My Plan EP
label: Domino/Drag City
description: Will Oldham's new EP suggests that his formidable catalog may be weighing heavily on him. Although it's hard to parse the intention behind Now Here's My Plan, less than reverential takes on Oldham classics would seem to suggest as much.

title: Reissues
label: Mute
description: The final installments in Mute's 25th anniversary Bad Seeds reissue campaign-- where each album is repackaged with B-sides, 5.1-channel stereo DVD audio mixes, and videos-- cover a period of great upheaval and rejuvenation.

title: Bubblegum Graveyard
label: Trouble in Mind
description: On its second LP, the weirdo Bloomington, Ind., garage/psych-rock trio focuses on vintage horror comic book imagery, but any shreds of meaning are second to the fever-pitched cosmic yelping of vocalist/guitarist Sonny Alexander.

title: Copenhagen Dreams
label: Norman
description: The Icelandic-born, Copenhagen-based composer created this soundtrack for Max Kestner's Cophenhagen Dreams, an impressionistic documentary study of that Danish city.

title: I Came From Nothing 3
label: self-released
description: The Atlanta rapper's latest mixtape is a dense, ambitious attempt to cultivate an entirely new style. But what Young Thug brings to the table isn't just a weird, experimental approach to rapping: he also offers presence, persona, mystique, and, potentially, star power.

title: Stay Calm
label: Fool's Gold
description: Wavves' Nathan Williams made this 22-minute beat tape with his brother. It's exactly what you’d expect from a 22-minute beat tape from Wavves and his brother.

title: Cut the World
label: Secretly Canadian
description: This live album, which boasts a new song in the form of the title track, draws from all of Antony's studio albums. The renditions of that back catalog are rendered so powerfully by the Danish National Chamber Orchestra that the originals seem almost incomplete by comparison.

title: Tropicalbacanal
label: Mad Decent
description: Confounding expectations, the Brazilian club brats' second album proper is an ambitious collection that expands their range-- including hook-ups with Caetano Veloso and Das Racist-- without sacrificing any of the mindless fun that made them such a lark the first time around.

title: Bricks in My Backpack 3
label: self-released
description: The third part of Troy Ave's Harry Powder Trilogy shows off the skills of a territorial Brooklyn rapper disinterested in what's going on outside of BK, but highly likely to be exercising his jurisdiction outside of the borough soon enough.

title: Funky Was the State of Affairs
label: Hardly Art
description: Andrew Savage and Jason Kelly's second album as Fergus and Geronimo continues the pair's preoccupation with lampooning hipster indie, proving to Williamsburg what Zappa was to San Francisco-- though with a slightly more conservative pallette.

title: AUN
label: Ash International
description: Fennesz composed this soundtrack for the Austrian director Edgar Honetschläger's AUN: The Beginning and the End of All Things, a 2011 feature film that imagines "a future world where life will be nothing but sensual." It principally drifts between fear, sadness, and loathing.

title: A Dot in Time
label: Temporary Residence
description: After four albums, an EP, stray tracks, and some videos, the Books called it quits this year. You couldn't ask for a better send-off than this lovingly compiled box set that collects all of their released music on vinyl and mp3 along with a DVD of their videos.

title: Intermezzo
label: Ideologic Organ
description: Originally issued as a self-released CD-R in 2011 by the Sun City Girls co-founder and master guitarist, this collection showcases Sir Richard Bishop's catalog-surfing range and monk-like patience.

title: Air Texture Vol. II
label: Air Texture
description: Vancouver's Loscil and Seattle's Rafael Anton Irisarri each curate a disc of Air Texture Vol. II, the second installment of  the Agriculture co-founder James Healy's electronic ambient series. Where Loscil favors dark hues and emotionally unreadable impressions of submerged movement, Irisarri cultivates an air of preoccupied melancholy.

title: Looping State Of Mind Remixe EP
label: Kompakt
description: This EP finds Junior Boys, Blondes, and Mohn (Jörg Burger and Wolfgang Voigt) remixing tracks from the Field's 2011 album Looping State of Mind. The pleasures here are traditional, and minor, but they're still pleasures.

title: Antibalas
label: Daptone
description: Antibalas swaps didactic specificity for sneaky allegory, torn-from-the-headlines trendiness for generations of weight, and the catalytic spark of the freshly-minted young radical for the perseverance of the long-struggling citizen, making for protest music without an expiration date.

title: Silencing Machine
label: Century Media
description: The longtime Chicago black metal band get back to basics, eschewing the experimentation of 2010's genre-bending Addicts: Black Meddle, Part II for a hard-hitting, riff-heavy appoach. It suits them.

title: Atra Mors
label: Profound Lore
description: The N.J. funeral doom legends' first album in five years is an obstacle course that rewards endurance with one of the most oppressive, majestic hours of music since they eked out their last one.

title: On Jones Beach
label: Three Lobed
description: Comprising Lee Ranaldo, David Watson and drummer Tony Buck, Glacial's debut full-length album is a masterpiece in blurring and burning the edges, riding the divide between chaos and melody like a skateboarder gliding on a rail.

title: Holograms
label: Captured Tracks
description: On their self-titled debut, the Stockholm band offer synth-driven pop songs that nod to post-punk and hardcore. Holograms focus on weighty topics like isolation, industrialization, and being ashamed of their country's history, but their hooks can be outright jovial.

title: Showtime
label: self-released
description: Showtime isn't the home run some of the Chicago rapper's fans might have been waiting for, but its genuine diversity and ambition has a wide appeal that feels like a major step forward after a relatively quiet period.

title: Graceland: 25th Anniversary Edition
label: Legacy
description: The 25th anniversary reissue of Paul Simon's Graceland shows how the album gave a human face to the perception of South Africa during apartheid by synthesizing geographically disparate musical strains that turned out to be remarkably complementary.

title: Le Trièdre fertile / Granulations-Sillages / Franges du Signe
label: Recollection GRM
description: The inaugural reissues from Editions Mego's new imprint are French composer and "musique concrète" inventor Pierre Schaeffer's last composition (and lone purely electronic work) and a composition from his student Guy Reibel that explores "the mathematical idea of the limit."

title: Reverence to Stone
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: The two songs on the crusty Seattle doom band's excellent second album, their first since 2008, clock in at 14 and 20 minutes, respectively, and yet it still feels like they're holding out on us.

title: Early Birds
label: Morr
description: This collection of the Icelandic band's first experiments predates their 2001 debut, Yesterday Was Dramatic - Today Is OK. It makes for a strange listen in 2012.

title: C.A.R.
label: Anticon
description: David Cohn's latest LP is a fine chronicle of the amiable pessimism and occasional nihilism of a rapping Bukowski who can't seem to find a way out of the condition in which he finds himself.

title: Blur 21
label: Parlophone
description: This sprawling set comprises all seven Blur albums, three DVDs, and five-and-a-half hours' worth of rarities. For its breadth and complexity, the box tells a simple story: Blur are a band that did an astonishing amount of different things really, really well.

title: Lost Lost: Demos, Sounds, Alternate Takes & Unused Songs 1999-2004
label: Goner
description: On a handful of releases in the early 2000s, the trio of Jay Reatard, Alicja Trout, and Rich Crook mastered a stabby sort of punk/new wave hybrid. Lost Lost is a collection of rarities for Lost Sounds, a group that really didn't have many non-rarities.

title: Sorry
label: Deranged
description: The Vancouver punk band's fast, threatening 19-minute sophomore record is compulsively listenable due in no small part to vocalist Mish Way's melodic but intimidating approach.

title: Do You Know Who I Am?
label: self-released
description: For a rapper so perfectly suited to 2012 sensibilities, the rising Chicago teen Sasha Go Hard showcases an exhilarating return to tradition on her promising new mixtape. It's exciting to feel an MC grow palpably better, brandishing tough-talking tunnel-vision confidence.

title: Sugar Reissues
label: Merge
description: Merge's remastered reissues of Bob Mould's early-1990s post-Hüsker Dü records Copper Blue, Beaster, and FU:EL are wonderfully presented documents of a punk legend starting over creatively and emotionally and succeeding beyond his and anyone's expectations.

title: God Forgives, I Don't
label: Def Jam
description: Despite guest spots from the likes of Jay-Z, André 3000, and Dr. Dre, the victory lap crowning Rick Ross' four-year rise to dominance still feels depressingly earthbound.

title: Regional Surrealism
label: Planet Mu
description: The Glasgow-based graphic artist's mostly instrumental Regional Surrealism brings together half-remembered childhood memories, severe dreams of the future, pastoral-electronic wistfulness, and a guest spot from Mogwai's Stuart Braithwaite.

title: Cellar Door
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Although the spotlight has shifted from Balearic pop in recent times, London duo the Idjut Boys are unlikely to care, having been trekking that breezy coast for nearly two decades. Astonishingly, this is their debut album, a warm, comforting collection with a wriggling focus.

title: Advaitic Songs
label: Drag City
description: Following in the path of 2009's God Is Good, Om incorporate instruments like tabla, cello, and flute on their fifth collection, Advaitic Songs. Diversity, it turns out, can be a diluting agent.

title: Playin' Me
label: Hyperdub
description: The South London producer/singer's latest album is consistently, deceptively understated. But its juxtaposition of complex drum patterns, slow-motion melodies, and heavily floating basslines makes it feel completely immersive.

title: Liquid Swords: Chess Box Deluxe Edition
label: Geffen/Get On Down
description: As a solo artist, GZA was essentially everything that distinguished Wu-Tang Clan from other crews: strictly chess, kung-fu, battle raps, investigative reports, mysticism. This masterful 1995 collection is the most potent distillation of that aesthetic.

title: White Math / Polymorph
label: Software
description: The two-track, 12" follow-up to Benjamin John Power's full-length debut as Blanck Mass last year moves surprisingly closer towards his work with Fuck Buttons, without fully committing to that band's fondness for abject terror.

title: Rebirth
label: Interscope
description: Rebirth is a perfect companion to Jamaica's independence. It reaches back to the era of ska, travels through the era of rockers and roots reggae, and demonstrates the power of the music today.

title: Handwritten
label: Mercury
description: In the past Brian Fallon managed to transform his icons into communal mythology. He sounds content to let his references do the heavy lifting on the Gaslight Anthem's fourth album, a collection that has its share of flaws and saving graces.

title: Reservation EP
label: True Panther
description: The 20-year-old Detroit native's first full-length to feature all original beats showcases her as the rare rapper who's copped a great deal of contemporary popular hip-hop and R&B and come out the other side as purely herself. Angel Haze may be the perfect avatar for hip-hop in 2012.

title: Undersea
label: Anti-
description: The Brooklyn band has described this four-song release as "an EP in length, but well beyond that in scope." If Hospice and Burst Apart were dark, rolling hills headed towards catharsis, here's the bottom.

title: Eremita
label: Candlelight
description: The Emperor co-founder and vocalist has moved far beyond black metal on his latest solo album, a collection that occasionally reveals his more savage roots, but succeeds by and large with elements like saxophone, Middle Eastern melodies, hand drums, and Evanescence-style refrains.

title: Jared's Lot
label: Spectrum Spools
description: Gary War's masterfully constructed third collection of experimental punk, synth tweakery, and distressed club beats showcases some of his cleanest-sounding production to date. It can be as fun to navigate (and as deeply psychedelic) as a Choose Your Own Adventure tale.

title: Correct Behavior
label: Kanine
description: The Roanoke, Va., band's second album sees them breaking out of their lo-fi origins, featuring production from the Raveonettes' Sune Rose Wagner. Correct Behavior is a step towards maturity, but in this case growing up just means growing louder.

title: Never
label: Rough Trade
description: Mica Levi's second album proper is forged from absence, dissonance, flat surfaces, and sharp edges-- a brave and tricky step down a path that terminates somewhere more elemental and holistic than "experimental pop music."

title: TNGHT EP
label: Warp/Luckyme
description: On their debut EP, the production duo of Lunice Fermin Pierre II (Lunice) and Ross Birchard (Hudson Mohawke) put together 16 minutes of the most brazen, positively huge beats this year.

title: In Decay
label: Ghostly
description: Most of the material on this 13-track, digital-only, rarities compilation was recorded prior to Seth Haley's 2011 Com Truise debut, Galactic Melt.

title: Tipped Bowls
label: Kompakt
description: Taragana Pyjarama's debut full-length sweats the small stuff, on a record that's minute, intricate, and pretty in strikingly coherent fashion, making for a pleasingly unusual Kompakt release.

title: Silencio
label: Drag City
description: The Stereolab frontwoman's latest solo LP renders her old band's political focus into a sort of fashionable socialism, for a breezy, pretty record that occasionally bows beneath overpowering and obvious political theories.

title: Major
label: Sargent House
description: On Major, Fang Island write vocal melodies and lyrics the same way they write riffs, simple yet very enthusiastic smile-triggers that are designed to be doubled and tripled for effect. It's an admirable level of positivity that's nevertheless ripe for resentment.

title: Shrines
label: 4AD
description: A year and a half after Purity Ring surfaced with the song "Ungirthed", the young Edmonton, Alberta, duo has released a proper debut, a compulsively listenable collection of dubbed-out retro-futuristic indie pop. Shrines is not about range, offering instead subtly different versions of a single, near-perfect idea.

title: Country Funk 1969-1975
label: Light in the Attic
description: Light in the Attic's new compilation pieces together a non-geographical scene that really cohered only in hindsight, the collection's effusive engagement with a wide range of materials and perspectives successfully binding these disparate artists together.

title: Outsider/In: The Collection
label: Demon
description: Gathering tracks from his work in the Auteurs and Baader Meinhof as well as his solo career, this compilation is a fine encapsulation of his misanthropic world-- it's flawed, ugly, and doesn't work quite right.

title: Take The Kids Off Broadway
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Foxygen began as two L.A. high school kids obsessed with the Brian Jonestown Massacre, and like their heroes they excel at mixing and matching 1960s and 70s rock touchstones into an appealing and highly referential collage.

title: Fantasea
label: self-released
description: The 21-year-old Harlem rapper's new mixtape is an often thrilling document of a phenomenally gifted performer in a state of flux: between rapper and singer, between dance and hip-hop, between building on last winter's raunchily transcendent single "212" and trying out new approaches.

title: Gossamer
label: Columbia
description: Three difficult years in the making, Gossamer is an overwhelming album about being overwhelmed, a bold torrent of maximalist musical ideas, repressed anger, and unchecked anxiety.

title: Icky Blossoms
label: Saddle Creek
description: This Tilly and the Wall side project's Dave Sitek-produced debut alternates between caffeinated synth-pop, nocturnal bar crawls, and straight-up electroclash revival.

title: Exo
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: Eighteen months after Matthew Arkell and Aaron David Ross released the Giza EP under their Gatekeeper alias, they return with a 35-minute LP that sounds gigantic, often gloriously dumb, and, in its finest moments, promisingly brazen.

title: Grace & Lies
label: No Quarter
description: The Brooklyn band's second album takes its cues from folk, but not the kind that gathers children around a crackling campfire. Instead, Grace & Lies is unnerving, inscrutable, and restrained in a fashion that only exacerbates the listener's curiosity.

title: A Collection of Rarities and Previously Unreleased Material
label: Ribbon Music
description: This set from the lo-fi pop eccentric gathers odds and ends from across his career. But weirdly it functions surprisingly well as an album, documenting changes in his sonic evolution and singular sense of humor along the way.

title: Life Is Good
label: Def Jam
description: Nas' 10th studio album, featuring production work from NO I.D., Buckwild, Salaam Remi, the late Heavy D, and Swizz Beatz, is his strongest in a few presidential administrations.

title: Strange Passion: Explorations in Irish Post Punk 1980-83
label: Finders Keepers
description: Strange Passion consists of tracks from Irish post-punk, DIY, and electronic musicians circa 1980-83. Lovingly pulled from rare vinyl and cassette releases by Dublin DJ Darren McCreesh, the collection carries an uncommon weight.

title: Pacific Standard Time
label: Day & Night
description: The L.A.-based duo of Filip Nikolic and Jeffrey Paradise, who have spent time in the orbit of Junior Senior and the Rapture, create an album of functional music befitting the project name.

title: Erika Spring EP
label: Cascine
description: The debut solo release from Au Revoir Simone's Erika Spring continues her main band's impulse toward mood over chirpy melody and tempers bombastic 1980s synth-pop influences into a dreamy and purposeful EP.

title: MTMTMK
label: Moshi Moshi
description: Esau Mwamwaya and Johan Hugo's latest melds together Euro-pop, kwela, bhangra and moombahton and has guests including Amadou & Mariam and Baaba Maal.

title: Pisces Iscariot
label: EMI
description: Billy Corgan's 1990s hot streak was fueled by self-loathing and self-aggrandizement, the equal and opposite manifestations of a whopping ego. The reissue of the Smashing Pumpkins' 1994 odd-and-ends collection showcases his ability to write colossal electric odysseys and wispy love songs.

title: Idea of Happiness
label: Modular
description: Four years after their debut, the Australian band do away with the "rock" half of their "electro-rock" equation in favor of a dance-friendly sound made for island-hopping.

title: I Make Lists EP
label: Hum and Buzz
description: The UK dubstep producer's first long-form release since her 2010 Hyperdub debut is an entirely different beast: I Make Lists reaches far beyond the London scene to the global club underground.

title: Hypnotic Nights
label: Warner Bros.
description: The Nashville brothers' seventh album, their first for a major label, was produced by the Black Keys' Dan Auerbach. Coming from a fuzz-pop band that has just two members and three guitar strings to its name, Hypnotic Nights covers a deceptively wide swath of sonic terrain.

title: Woody at 100: The Woody Guthrie Centennial Collection
label: Smithsonian Folkways
description: Okemah, Okla.'s most famous export might have turned 100 this July if Huntington's disease hadn't wasted him back in 1967. To honor the centennial, the Smithsonian organized this 57-track Folkways box set featuring the most notable of his recorded songs winnowed down to two discs and a third filled with unreleased material.

title: Yellow & Green
label: Relapse
description: A decade into their career, Baroness continue to take chances. On this double album, that means experimenting with length and adding a new focus on melody. It's an epic record that is heavy in a new way.

title: Faustian Echoes EP
label: Dämmerung Arts
description: No stranger to the epic or the ambitious, the Portland dark metal band Agalloch's new EP consists of one 21-minute track inspired by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust.

title: Wink With Both Eyes
label: Night People
description: The Brattleboro, Vt., duo has produced one of the year's most thoroughly alien-sounding pop albums. The fully analog Wink With Both Eyes is teeming with eccentricities.

title: Don't Like
label: self-released
description: The young Chicago rapper and Chief Keef sound-alike signed to Def Jam this month. His debut mixtape is an extension of he and Keef's shared aesthetic, and in that sense it's a worthy follow-up to one of the most important mixtapes of the year.

title: Children of Desire
label: Katorga Works
description: A product of their city's thriving DIY punk and hardcore scenes, the Tampa, Fla. band features members of Neon Blud, Cult Ritual, and the Dry County. Their ambitious second album is an outsized, emotionally rich pop record that practically begs for your attention.

title: Channel Orange
label: Def Jam
description: Frank Ocean has quickly proven himself to be among the most gifted singer-songwriters of his generation. His major-label debut swings from Stevie-style keyboard breeziness to 90s R&B to mystic psych rock to crunching 8-bit funk without thinking twice. It already feels like a classic.

title: LateNightTales Presents Music for Pleasure
label: Late Night Tales
description: LateNightTales commandeer Groove Armada's Tom Findlay to compile a yacht rock primer for the series. Findlay inserts transitions between the very familiar source material to make the composite parts flow as one for an unsurprising but satisfying compilation.

title: Russian Roulette
label: Decon
description: The Beverly Hills-born producer goes in a new direction on his third solo album, a sequence of short instrumentals spliced together with lines of dialogue from records or films and guest raps from Danny Brown, Boldy James, and Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire, among others.

title: Drought EP
label: Season of Mist
description: For the last decade, the mysterious French metal shapeshifters have made some of the most fitful and demanding heavy records in the world. Here they follow 2010's masterful Paracletus and last year's one-track Diabolus Absconditus with a six-song EP.

title: Live From the Underground
label: Island Def Jam
description: Two years since Mississippi rapper K.R.I.T. broke the scene with Krit Wuz Here, he's still wearing his Southern heritage like a diamond-encrusted chip on his shoulder.

title: Unsound
label: Fire
description: A decade into their second career, Mission of Burma's core sound remains the same. But as far as relentless, rock-solid lifers go, they're up there with the best, burying delight in the details.

title: New Memory
label: self-released
description: The young Florida songwriter Malcom Lacey's self-therapeutic style of confessional ambient electro-pop hums with quiet urgency. His third collection of 2012 offers the boldest version of his sound to date.

title: Total Dust
label: Polyvinyl
description: Brian Borcherdt is mostly known for his day job as a member of Holy Fuck, but he's been releasing cathartic solo albums preoccupied with the specter of death for the past decade. On Total Dust, he seems to be moving towards a place where he accepts his fate.

title: Debo Band
label: Sub Pop
description: On this impressive debut, the 11-piece Boston band puts its own spin on Ethopian music, mixing a few originals in with a well-chosen selection of "Golden Era" compositions, folk tunes, and troubadour songs.

title: DJ-Kicks
label: !K7
description: In 2007, Digitalism and Justice could feel like an adrenalized alternative to the lack-of-excess that defined the glut of inessential minimal techno. In the midst of the new dance-meets-rock order, the German electro house duo's DJ-Kicks mix of slick computer love and a little rock swagger feels kind of quaint.

title: Skelethon
label: Rhymesayers
description: Aesop Rock's sixth album, his first without any Blockhead beats or guest rappers, evokes the self-doubt, sleepless nights, and isolated focus required to finish something great. This is rap as Rorschach blot.

title: The Memories
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Erik Gage and Kyle Handley from White Fang don their Underwater Peoples clothes for a fat-free, 19-minute-long record as the Memories that doesn't mess around when it comes to simple sentiments and riffs.

title: Reissues
label: Edsel
description: The reissues of the first four albums by Everything But the Girl tell the story of a young band searching for an identity to call its own. They veer from ramshackle Brit indie to gaudy college rock, soft-focus dream pop blind to Thatcherian reality, and lo-fi takes on big 1980s pop.

title: Deep Time
label: Hardly Art
description: The Texan duo changes its name from Yellow Fever, trading in nursery rhymes for scene kids for a deliberately small, dark take on post-punk. And it suits them.

title: Julian Plenti Lives... EP
label: Matador
description: Interpol leader Paul Banks' second Julian Plenti release bears three covers and two originals, and raises the question of where Banks is headed with the project.

title: Swing Lo Magellan
label: Domino
description: Dave Longstreth guides Dirty Projectors toward their most human and least ornate release yet. It's an album of deeply appealing simplicity that mixes subtle folk protest and gorgeous paeans to young love.

title: Whispers in the Dark
label: Dovecote
description: The Chicago duo's debut album brings together new age textures, plenty of clipped and distressed vocals, lush R&B notes, rhythms that nod to Southern hip-hop.

title: This Ain't Chicago: The Underground Sound of UK House and Acid 1987-1991
label: Strut
description: Lovingly compiled by Padded Cell's Richard Sen, This Ain't Chicago offers a snapshot of a key era in UK dance muisc, forgoing obviously choices for a clutch of tunes largely forgotten by history.

title: Totally
label: Everloving
description: San Diego's Andrew Caddick specializes in bummer summer jams for beach bums, taking angular surf-guitar guitar lines, reverb-heavy vocals, and understated-to-the-point-of-flatness rhythms, then soaking them in disaffected darkness.

title: Warm Pulse EP
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: The L.A. duo returns with another collection of original productions. It's easily the darkest and most ominous-sounding thing they've done so far, with a steely blue-and-gray palette and big walls of bass clang.

title: Confess
label: 4AD
description: George Lewis Jr. adopts a bad-boy persona for the pristine follow-up to 2010's Forget. It's a laser-focused, sharply posturing collection that eulogizes the coldness of modern relationships, and the confusion of lust over love.

title: III
label: Profound Lore
description: The shadowy Bay Area quartet combine black metal with shoegaze, post-hardcore, screamo, and even indie rock on their chaotic, aggressive sophomore collection, their first for Profound Lore.

title: Rebirth of Detroit
label: Ruff Draft
description: J Dilla's second posthumous album features 21 tracks of classically raw Motor City rap. Unlike his first posthumous collection, most of the tracks on Rebirth have rappers on them, a coterie of Detroit MCs who double as Dilla worshippers.

title: Tapes
label: !K7
description: The Oxford band's eclectic installment in the German label !K7's Tapes series meshes together a Carl Craig remix, a Caribou edit, Nicolas Jaar, Konono Nº1, Blood Orange, Clark, South African artist Condry Ziqubu, and others.

title: Song Cycle / Discover America / Clang of the Yankee Reaper
label: Bella Union
description: Last year, the seminal American composer and arranger put out Arrangements, Vol. 1 on his Bananastan label. He has now reissued 1968's towering Song Cycle, 1972's calypso-themed Discover America, and the 1975 songbook record Clang of the Yankee Reaper.

title: High Summer EP
label: Sincerely Yours
description: This new five-song EP finds the Swedish duo cribbing T.I., Lil Wayne, and The-Dream, among others, for their familiar blend of lovelorn indie pop and bouncy Mediterranean club beats.

title: Mostly No
label: Fat Cat
description: In a year of  garage rockers folding rockabilly numbers, fuzz wars, and ambient brain-slushers into their attack, Milk Maid leader Martin Cohen sticks to a tried-and-true DIY template on his Manchester, England band's second LP.

title: Meat Mountain EP
label: Lujo
description: The promising Chicago psych-tinged synth-pop group's new EP comes on the heels of 2011's Confetti and the accompanying Confetti Reprise. It finds the dual-drumming quintet casually nudging themselves in a different, more expansive direction.

title: Gentle Stream
label: Subliminal Sounds
description: Sharing members with Swedish psych-rock monsters Dungen, the Amazing have a similar reverence for the music of the past. But their mix of folk and psych has more going for it than just retro pastiche.

title: MMG Presents: Self Made 2
label: Warner Bros.
description: On this newest Maybach showcase, Rick Ross shares the spotlight with his blue-collar, modestly striving underbosses Wale, Stalley, and Meek Mill as well as a criminally underutilized Gunplay.

title: Write Me Back
label: RCA
description: R. Kelly's newest is a collection of soul and R&B throwbacks that doesn't always cut it production-wise but does feature some brilliant singing. And when you're talking R. Kelly albums, that counts for a lot.

title: Staycations
label: self-released
description: Appealing to Britain's National Trust for help making Staycations, the herky-jerky art-pop trio recorded its second album in old mansions, historic gardens, haunted attics, and storied bedrooms across the UK.

title: Holiday
label: self-released
description: Nick Principe is a collaborator and childhood friend of Antlers frontman Pete Silberman, and his Port St. Willow project shares much of that band's sonic and emotional leanings. His debut album is an absorbing and promising record.

title: Standing at the Sky's Edge
label: Mute
description: Richard Hawley has described his seventh album as his "angry record." Musically, the formula he's refined for more than a decade has been blown up and tripped out with loud guitars and nods to mid-1990s bong-addled British psych-rock.

title: Dreamin' Wild
label: Light in the Attic
description: Originally released in 1979, only to sit in the teenaged Emerson brothers' home studio for decades, Donnie and Joe's sole record showcases a prodigal talent for blue-eyed soul and landlocked yacht rock that's only just getting its dues.

title: The Tarnished Gold
label: Sub Pop
description: The L.A. band's first new album in 10 years, which features an Ariel Pink guest spot, feels every bit out of time and place as their debut did back in 2000. It's like an immaculately preserved 1970s obscurity stumbled upon in your local record store.

title: Under the Pale Moon
label: Sacred Bones
description: Fresh & Onlys guitarist Wymond Miles' second solo release of the year was quickly written and recorded after the deaths of his closest friend and some family members.

title: L'Enfant Sauvage
label: Roadrunner
description: Gojira's fifth album is the French metal act's best work to date. This quartet's nothing if not an adroit and agile rock band, one prone to acrobatic guitar lines and rhythmic shifts capable of inducing whiplash.

title: Longtime Companion
label: Polyvinyl
description: The third LP from San Francisco garage-poppers came to be after main man Sonny Smith and his girlfriend of a decade parted ways. But where most breakup albums aim for the rawest nerve, Smith keeps a characteristically cool head.

title: Pop Etc
label: Rough Trade
description: The Morning Benders return with a new name and a new sound. This collection draws inspiration from leader Chris Chu's childhood obsession with R&B groups like Boyz II Men and synth-heavy pop artists like Madonna.

title: Frigid Stars / Barely Real EP / The White Birch
label: Numero Group
description: The Numero Group label applies its careful and thorough approach to the music of 1990s slowcore stalwarts Codeine, with dazzling results.

title: Constantinople
label: Neurot
description: Sera Timms' cathedral-sized voice is the focus of this L.A. trio's debut. She softens the role of doom-metal bandleader, doling out lyrics about dishonor, mortality, and pain with a well-developed sense of what sounds pretty.

title: NO
label: Hydra Head
description: This noise-rock/metal collective includes members of Isis, Converge, and Cave In. Their fifth album is fucked up, individualistic, and unrelentingly apocalyptic while remaining life-affirming.

title: Trouble
label: Casablanca
description: Despite the Oxford-based house producer's goofy moniker and preferred costuming (feathered wings, feathered headdresses, stegosaurus spines, etc.), Totally Enormous Extinct Dinosaurs' pop-infused debut isn't incredibly showy.

title: haha i'm sorry EP
label: self-released
description: Kitty Pryde came on the scene with the YouTube hit "Okay Cupid" in May, and since that time the 19-year-old Florida rapper has worked with Riff Raff, been photographed with Danny Brown, and also made this short EP.

title: Class Clown Spots a UFO
label: Fire
description: Following January's Let's Go Eat the Factory, GBV's second reunion LP is shorter, punchier, and livelier than its predecessor. Last time, Tobin Sprout's input felt especially triumphant. Here, it's Robert Pollard's show.

title: Everybody's Got It Easy But Me
label: In the Red
description: Over the course of seven albums, Lars Finberg has couched his complaints in cryptic, cheeky wordplay, and a fractious sound that hotwires elements of garage rock, post-punk, and new wave. His newest LP is at once his most lyrically direct and musically exploratory to date.

title: Modeselektion Vol. 02
label: Monkeytown
description: The second volume of the Berlin duo Modeselektor's Modeselektion compilation series includes carefully sequenced contributions from Monolake, Prefuse 73, Clark, and Mouse on Mars, among others. On it, they turn away from the dancefloor to a more inward journey.

title: Safety Net EP
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: This New Jersey-based DJ/producer, most often found inside sets of remix parentheses, offers his first official EP. Across five songs, he attemps to corrall his themes of smooth jazz, early-1990s rave soundtracks, rare samples, R&B vocals, and ambient percussive sounds.

label: Unknown
description: The 17-year-old Brooklyn rapper Joey Bada$$, the most visible member of the Progressive Era artist collective, is a young man with an old soul, and his debut mixtape showcases a prodigous MC with a vision.

title: Oshin
label: Captured Tracks
description: DIIV's compelling debut album is a gorgeous and unusually melodic dream-pop record built around verses and choruses that are unusually fluid and intuitive.

title: Red Night
label: Warp
description: Ditching some of the post-punk allure that previously earned them Siouxsie Sioux and Karen O comparisons, the Brooklyn duo shifts into the murkier, heavy-lidded realm of electropop on their second Warp LP.

title: The Thought Adjusters
artist: Father Yod and the Source Family
label: Drag City
description: In the late 1960s and 70s, the Source Family and their leader, Father Yod, espoused a spiritual, philosophical, and ethical lifestyle. But if you haven't encountered any Source music before, this newest archival release will more likely rework your ideas of long psych freakouts than your notions of spirituality.

title: In Motion #1
label: Beat Records
description: This quasi-Cinematic Orchestra release-- in fact a curated seven-song set, of which three are theirs-- was made to score a collection of avant-garde films, and feels strangely incomplete without the inspirational source material.

title: Worship
label: Dead Oceans
description: There's a textural richness and emotional depth to the New York noise-rock trio's toned-down third album, elements that weren't always apparent on their previous collections. The best songs feel like the work of another band entirely.

title: Slaughterhouse
label: In the Red
description: Ty Segall is on a tear. Slaughterhouse may be his heaviest and loudest album, but its extra heft doesn't come at the expense of Segall's melodic gifts and  Nuggets-schooled economy.

title: Deep in the Night EP
label: Fool's Gold
description: It's helpful to consider the French producer's new EP as an addendum to his 2010 full-length Long Distance, continuing as it does in a similar vein rather than expanding into any particular new ground.

title: FÆMIN
label: Bleak
description: The strength of the Portuguese atmospheric doom band's third and most high-profile full-length lies in its strangeness: There's not much else out there that sounds like this heady mixture of Godflesh and Neurosis at their most pointed.

title: Wild Peace
label: Slumberland
description: The London band's long-awaited Slumberland debut is a collection of pure, dreamy indie rock laced with the more narcotic strains of shoegaze. There's a distinct delicacy to this reclusive music that forgoes superficial thrill for subtle absorption.

title: Valley Tangents
label: Drag City
description: The experimental duo's first album for Drag City, and the first since they escaped New York for Lehigh Valley, Penn., displays an increased technical proficiently unifying bits of prog, noise, baroque, and hip-hop.

title: iTunes Session
label: Jagjaguwar
description: This crisp in-studio EP offers takes on selections from Bon Iver as well as a Björk cover. It hints at what that album might have sounded like with more traditional production, but raises some familiar questions about the purpose of such a release.

title: Language
label: Arts & Crafts
description: There's a fundamental disconnect between the band that Zulu Winter seem to be and the music that appears on the buzzed-about London five-piece's debut LP.

title: Digital Native
label: Planet Mu
description: Italian composer Egisto Sopor's debut album for Planet Mu bears a lightness of touch that barely veils its insubstantial nature, in spite of the potent background against which it was conceived.

title: Music for the Quiet Hour / The Drawbar Organ EPs
label: Woe to the Septic Heart
description: Shackleton's 137-minute-long, 2xCD offering proves anything but bloated; instead, the double release is the British producer's strongest yet, immersive and shining with deliriousness, while continuing his nation's weird and wonderful relationship with dub.

title: The National Health
label: V2
description: On their fourth album in seven years, the British indie stalwarts remain true to form with an album that barely veers from the template laid by their debut.

title: Early Times
label: Drag City
description: This reissue collects the crude and exceedingly noisy early recordings of the Silver Jews, back when the band included Pavement's Stephen Malkmus and Bob Nastanovich.

title: Falling Off the Sky
label: Bar/None
description: On their first album in almost 20 years, the N.C. quartet invoke their R.E.M. and Alex Chilton-associated heyday and acknowledge they'll never be young again. Rather than simply reliving past glories, Peter Holsapple, Chris Stamey, and co. are trying to create new ones.

title: Bloodstreams
label: Hassle
description: On its debut LP, this punked-up Australian duo makes liberal use of volume and vitriol, but the songs are executed with the impulse that makes you go on the same roller coaster 12 times in a row. DZ Deathrays formed to play house parties, and they say they'll "most likely end at one," too.

title: Dog in the Fog EP
label: Software
description: Daniel Lopatin's 2011 album Replica gets the remix treatment in the form of a four-track EP, where Matmos, Surgeon, Richard Youngs, and Lopatin himself retool that record's modular approach

title: The Cherry Thing
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Cherry and the Swedish free jazz ensemble achieve a rare feat with the product of a four-day jam; a covers record that's both deeply personal for both parties, and possessed of a fleeting magic.

title: Looking 4 Myself
label: RCA
description: Usher's new album finds the R&B star holding his own with guests and producers including A$AP Rocky, Diplo, Noah "40" Shebib, Rick Ross, and more.

title: I Like to Keep Myself in Pain
label: Anti-
description: Hogan releases her fourth solo album in 20 years, a collection of covers that fit beautifully on the whole, if often all too comfortably.

title: Ruler of the Night
label: Hardly Art
description: Upgrading his solo project to a quartet and rechristening it Magic Trick, the Fresh & Onlys singer-songwriter offers a new, often surprsingly experimental collection that includes guitar squall, drum machines, and autoharp.

title: Life Has Not Finished With Me Yet
label: Saint Marie
description: Glen Johnson and his band are now very far from their indie pop beginnings, and here they've created the starkest and most self-consciously serious Piano Magic album so far.

title: Lucifer
label: Mexican Summer
description: Nudging their sound forward on their third LP, the married duo of Indra Dunis and Aaron Coyes offer a swirl of psych, synth-pop, reggae, and dub that incorporates the voice and presence of their son, Mikko.

title: Oceania
label: Caroline
description: Returning with a new band assembled via open auditions, Billy Corgan's first album in five years under the Smashing Pumpkins name finds him recapturing some of his inspiration.

title: CVI
label: Relapse
description: The heavy Atlanta rock'n'roll band's debut LP mixes the powerful, bluesy vocals of Mlny Parson-- equal parts riot grrl and gospel diva-- with vintage riffs and a big, retro vibe.

title: Occlusions
label: Editions Mego
description: Keith Fullerton Whitman's second album for Editions Mego this year was recorded live with the electronic musician in a state of "arbitrarily triggered blind rage." It sounds something like he took 2012's other release, Generators, and fed it through a cheese-grater.

title: Walk on Heads EP
label: Escho
description: Featuring members of Girlseeker, VÅR, and Sexdrome, the young Copenhagen punk band merges the noise and clangor of 1970s post-punk and no wave with the aggression of 1980s hardcore on this debut EP.

title: The Lost Tapes
label: Mute
description: This 3xCD set was distilled from 30 hours' worth of unissued material spanning the period from 1968 through 1977 by Can keyboardist Irmin Schmidt and his son-in-law and frequent collaborator Jono Podmore.

title: The Idler Wheel Is Wiser Than the Driver of the Screw and Whipping Cords Will Serve You More Than Ropes Will Ever Do
label: Epic
description: On Fiona Apple's first album in seven years, her sharp songwriting and vivid imagery have lost none of their power.

title: The Warmest Place
label: Ivy League
description: The debut full-length from Australian pop singer Catherine Kelleher feels frozen in a moment it can't quite transcend.

label: Fat Possum
description: London sisters Colette and Hannah Thurlow offer their smoky, gothic, and buzzed-about (Rob Ellis-recorded and Alan Moulder-mixed) debut.

title: My God Is Blue
label: Record Makers
description: The French songwriter and multi-instrumentalist's fourth album finds him once again transcending his reputation as a European pop curiosity.

title: Limbo
label: Underwater Peoples
description: The Black Dice member's new solo effort features body-moving rhythms that are practically clean and clear, at least relative to his gnarled sonic universe.

title: Express Yourself EP
label: Mad Decent
description: This colorful six-song EP, set to come out near the end of 2011 but just seeing the light of day, feels like a well-deserved victory lap.

title: Manifest!
label: Fat Possum
description: Friends sprung from the Brooklyn DIY scene on the back of their 2011 single "I'm His Girl" and the band's debut feeds off a strand of NY's past that's perilously close to being bled dry.

title: Into the Lair of the Sun God
label: Profound Lore
description: Led by talented multi-instrumentalist Chris Black (Nachtmystium, High Spirits), the Chicago retro-metal band's fifth LP is a concept album about a warrior who wants to kill the sun.

title: Negaverse
label: Mexican Summer
description: Following on their 2010 debut, Ghost Blonde, the Montreal noise-pop band returns with a five-song EP that finds them changing up their style from one track to the next.

title: Instrumental Tape 2
label: self-released
description: A year after his out-of-nowhere Instrumental Mixtape, we're familiar with Clams Casino's hip-hop production style, and the songs he's making beats for have more memorable hooks and verses. Do his productions still work well on their own?

title: The Bravest Man in the Universe
label: XL
description: Bobby Womack's first album of original material in 18 years finds him working with Damon Albarn and XL owner and producer Richard Russell with help from Lana Del Rey, the late Gil Scott-Heron, Warp studio wiz Kwes, and others.

title: Cauldron of the Wild
label: Profound Lore
description: On their third album, the first for Profound Lore, this Portland doom band's powered by vocalist Uta Plotkin's bluesy, ballsy, and commanding vocals.

title: Composed
label: Leaf
description: The promising Seattle composer and songwriter's handmade orchestral pop record features David Byrne, tropicalia legend Caetano Veloso, Deerhoof's Greg Saunier, Wilco's Nels Cline, and Craig Wedren of Shudder to Think, among others.

title: Salton Sea
label: Friends of Friends
description: The Danish producer and drummer takes a break from WhoMadeWho for this solo album, a confident collection of pop-leaning sparklers and sweeping instrumentals.

title: One Day I'm Going to Soar
label: BMG
description: Arriving 27 years after the last Dexys Midnight Runners' album, the idosyncratic One Day I'm Going to Soar is a comeback LP about being stuck in a self-defeating cycle.

title: Mysterious Phonk: The Chronicles of SpaceGhostPurrp
label: 4AD
description: This Florida rapper/producer's 4AD debut combines 1990s gangsta tropes, the codeine-sipping pace of Southern rap, New York's subzero bleakness, and the overarching vulgarity that's come to define the hip-hop of his home state.

title: Traps
label: Sub Pop
description: The power-pop band's third album, their second for Sub Pop, mingles the barely contained anti-folk frustrations of Violent Femmes with a hearty Midwestern fondness for riffs and boss solos.

title: Zummo With an X
label: Optimo Music
description: From modern classical to disco classicism, Peter Zummo shadowed Arthur Russell's cello lines with his peerless trombone work. His first album of solo compositions, from 1985, has been reissued on vinyl by JD Twitch of record obsessive DJ duo Optimo.

title: Freak Puke
label: Ipecac
description: Under the name "Melvins Lite," Buzz Osborne and Dale Crover pull away from the younger half of their band, adding double bassist Trevor Dunn (Mr. Bungle) to cover Macca, improvise, and turn plenty-weird songs into still-weirder jams.

title: There's No Leaving Now
label: Dead Oceans
description: The Swedish folkie's third album is the first to feature multi-tracking. He's still driven by his wandering spirit, but these songs have the feel of someone exploring a nature trail in his own backyard.

title: Triple F Life: Friends, Fans & Family
label: Warner Bros.
description: Featuring Nicki Minaj, B.o.B, Drake, Ludacris, and airy, stroboscopic beats, Waka Flocka Flame's second album exchanges his debut's antisocial charisma, grim ambience, and seismic street impact for something more amenable to pop stardom.

title: Ursprung
label: Dial
description: Merging live instruments with editing software, Hendrik Weber, aka Pantha du Prince, teams with Stephan Abry of Krautrock-as-indie-pop act Workshop for a collection that largely abandons Pantha's bright and glacial digital palette.

title: Love Me Oh Please Love Me EP
label: Deek
description: The London producer Nathan Jenkins, who once successfully combined Pet Sounds and the music of J Dilla, offers a frequently vocal-led EP of five original tracks and a Robert Wyatt cover.

title: Do Things
label: Paw Tracks
description: For his second album on Animal Collective's Paw Tracks label, the Oxford, Miss., musician replaces his ukelele with spritely synths, airy acoustic guitars, and hints of psychedelia.

title: Synthetica
label: Mom & Pop
description: Emily Haines spends much of Metric's fifth album pondering the way the human mind is transformed by artificial versions of natural experiences. She also duets with Lou Reed.

title: In Our Heads
label: Domino
description: Hot Chip's fifth full-length, a meditation on positivity, is their most playful and colorful record to date.

title: Blood Speaks
label: V2
description: On their sophomore album, the London-based blues and folk duo of Katherine Blamire and Jessica Davies found a sympathetic ear in longtime PJ Harvey collaborator Head.

title: Dub Egg
label: Matador
description: On their second album, the first for Matador, Austin four-piece the Young dial down their psych-rock impulses to focus on classic songcraft.

title: Bat Chain Puller
label: Zappa
description: Captain Beefheart's 1976 album Bat Chain Puller was a record that, for many, existed only in promising snatches through subsequent albums, a fragmented text never quite assembled. The tapes have finally found release in an edition available through a subsidiary of the Frank Zappa estate.

title: Umskiptar
label: Byelobog
description: Without Varg Vikernes, the black metal story doesn't happen, or at least it doesn't merit a book deal. But how do you treat the legacy and output of someone who's done so much to build a sound, yet is also a murderer and a bigot?

title: 1991 EP
label: Interscope
description: The Harlem-based MC's long-delayed first official release finds her standing at a number of interesting junctions, if not yet having committed to a solid path.

title: Radlands
label: Rough Trade
description: The Brit rockers' fourth album finds the band leaving behind the glitzy rafter-reaching attitude of 2010's Serotonin in favor of countryish melodies, acoustic guitars, and gospel choirs.

title: Hope in Dirt City
label: Upper Class
description: The Edmonton MC has served as the official poet laureate of his hometown, so it's surprising the strength of his third album doesn't lie in his writing or his rapping.

title: A Painting of a Painting On Fire
label: RCMP
description: The Band of Horses member's debut solo LP was recorded by Chris Testa (P!nk, Matchbox 20) and features a hyperactive brand of 1970s rock full of big, shiny melodies and eager riffs.

title: Lex Hives
label: Disques Hives
description: On the Swedish garage rock group's fifth album, their proper followup to 2007's The Black and White Album, it sounds like they're still figuring things out.

title: Quarantine
label: Hyperdub
description: Veering from claustrophobic sci-fi dioramas to meditative synth drones to nakedly expressive confessionals, Laurel Halo's Hyperdub debut is unified by an underlying perspective and personality that commands attention yet still leaves plenty to the imagination.

title: LP
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: Following last year's split with Grimes, the Montreal musician releases an LP, a sprawling collection that explores extremes of spirituality in a digital world.

title: Aimlessness
label: Pampa
description: Jimmy Tamborello, best known for his work in the Postal Service, releases a third album of new material, a collection that mixes instrumentals and collaborations with guest vocalists like Baths and Nite Jewel.

title: Endless Flowers
label: Frenchkiss
description: The 1960s-nodding San Diego noise-pop band's third album is their best and also their most frustrating.

title: The Stoned Immaculate
label: Warner Bros.
description: Curren$y's latest album features Big K.R.I.T., Pharrell, 2 Chainz, Estelle, Young Jeezy, Wiz Khalifa, and a buzz-harshing Wale, among others.

title: Banga
label: Columbia
description: Patti Smith's new guitar-driven album, her first since 2007's Twelve, is a meditation on exploration and adventure.

title: Taranta
label: Believe
description: The 28-year-old Parisian born singer-songwriter's debut LP was inspired by madness, spider bites, and the hellish melancholy of early Cat Power records.

title: All of Us, Together
label: Lefse
description: Though Teen Daze is intent on calling himself a producer, it's helpful to view the British Columbia artist's debut LP within the frame of rock music.

title: Reverberations: Tape & Electronic Music 1961-1970
label: Important
description: This monumental box set collects the work of the 80-year-old composer, teacher, and electronic music pioneer: Reverberations fills a dozen discs in almost as many hours, laying substantial groundwork for every electronic drone artist and harsh noise terrorist to come.

label: Invada
description: While retaining the eerie, claustrophobic atmosphere of its predecessor, the second LP from Portishead mastermind Geoff Barrow's krautrock project boasts a brisker, more purposeful sequence.

title: Control System
label: Top Dawg
description: The least visible member of the Black Hippy collective, who Schoolboy Q has called a "human dictionary" and Kendrick Lamar "a wizardish genius," releases his exhilarating debut.

title: Trust EP
label: Mexican Summer
description: Joel Ford, who plays bass in Tigercity and records as as one half of Ford & Lopatin, offers a five-track solo EP that finds him widening his scope and edging away from outright pop.

title: Lillie: F-65
label: Season of Mist
description: Saint Vitus' first album in 17 years, the first to feature original vocalist Scott "Wino" Weinrich in 22 years, finds the hugely influential Los Angeles doom band flush with renewed energy.

title: Odd Renditions Vol. 001 EP
label: self-released
description: On the eve of a new full-length, the D.C. rapper releases an EP featuring reworked cuts by Bon Iver, Metronomy, Marvin Gaye, and k-os. They're remixes in the loose sense, but Oddisee treats them like duets.

title: A Joyful Noise
label: Columbia
description: Following 2009's Rick Rubin-produced Music for Men, the Portland trio's fifth album was handled by UK pop mastermind Xenomania, perhaps best known for helming Sugababes and Girls Aloud's clever post-millennial bubblegum.

title: WIXIW
label: Mute
description: Co-produced by Mute founder Daniel Miller (Depeche Mode, Yazoo), Liars' dark, largely electronic and sample-based latest album is a return to their adventurous, experimental roots. It's also the group's most human and fragile album to date.

title: Embracing the Lightless Depths
label: Profound Lore
