description: On their excellent second album, the Portland funeral doom band make every ounce of their weight count by knowing exactly how to counter it.

title: Sex, Drugs & Video Games
label: self-released
description: The Mississippi rapper's latest album, his first since 2008, features Big K.R.I.T., A$AP Rocky, 2 Chainz, Chris Brown, Bun B, Snoop Dogg, and Lil Wayne, among others.

title: Here Comes Everybody
label: Captured Tracks
description: The Wake, who recorded for Factory and Sarah, mixed nervously funky post-punk with bedroom synth-pop. After repressing two singles for Record Store Day, Captured Tracks has reissued the Glasgow band's 1985 sophomore LP along with non-album tracks from the era.

title: Among the Leaves
label: Caldo Verde
description: Mark Kozelek's sprawling, cathartic fifth album as Sun Kil Moon feels like the work of a songwriter clearing his palate.

title: Americana
label: Reprise
description: Neil Young's latest studio record, his first with Crazy Horse in nine years, isn't so much a covers collection as it is a concept album in the vein of Nick Cave's Murder Ballads.

title: Merciless
label: Type
description: After more than a decade of noise and drone made in small editions, the Ohio-based artist-- with the help of Marina Peterson, C. Spencer Yeh, and Jason Zeh-- offers his richest LP to date.

title: Generals
label: Saddle Creek
description: Laura Burhenn's second LP, again produced by Richard Swift, is a stylistically diverse collection of openhearted, politically engaged pop.

title: Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller II
label: Clone
description: The excellent second installment of Clone's four-part Drexciya retrospective continues in much the same manner as Vol. 1: short tracks of spackled, analog funk dominate, offering occasional clues about the Detroit duo's sci-fi mystery.

title: The Sister
label: Box of Cedar
description: Marissa Nadler's second full-length by way of her own Box of Cedar imprint is her most narcotic album to date.

title: Max Payne 3 OST
label: Rockstar
description: The L.A. noise-rock band's original score for Max Payne 3 replicates the third-person shooter action game's slow-motion frenzy.

title: A Monument
label: City Slang
description: Fronted by Corrina Repp and Joe Haege (Menomena, 31 Knots), the Portland quartet creates darkly lovely music-- and actual songs-- on its second LP.

title: Here
label: Vagrant
description: The onetime frontman of Ima Robot offers the next chapter in the ever-evolving mythology of Edward Sharpe with a surprisingly humble, homespun sophomore album.

title: What We Saw From the Cheap Seats
label: Sire
description: Now six albums into her career, Regina Spektor presents both her sentimentalism and her more childlike qualities with a certain defiance.

title: This Is PiL
label: PiL
description: For a band that built its name on ripping up the rule book, what do Public Image Ltd. sound like 20 years since their last album, and over 30 since their first?

title: Valtari
label: XL
description: The Icelandic post-rock band's longest-gestating LP abandons both the pop leanings of more recent releases and the volcanic dynamics of their earliest material but still sounds like the work of no other group.

title: Spirits
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The latest from this project from Eternal Tapestry guitarist Dewey Mahood is easily his warmest, most approachable record, filled with pastoral drones and swirling psychedelia.

title: King Tuff
label: Sub Pop
description: After making an album under the name Happy Birthday, Kyle Thomas returns with a new moniker and sharper songwriting chops, resulting an album that is long on distortion and short on subtlety, but still manages to transcend lo-fi.

title: Magic Hour
label: Interscope
description: Scissor Sisters' latest features collaborations with producers like Diplo, the Neptunes, and Boys Noize, but despite these club-friendly ringers the album is heavy on the ballads.

title: Diver
label: True Panther
description: Four years after their big and bombastic self-titled debut, Lemonade return with an album that functions in more pop-economical four-minute bursts, with tracks tempering the big-beat ballast with stripped-down slow jams.

title: Celebration Rock
label: Polyvinyl
description: The Vancouver's 2009 debut Post-Nothing was an emotional blast and also a sonic blur; the follow-up finds everything hitting louder and clearer than before, along with making a huge leap in songwriting technique.

title: Classical Curves
label: Night Slugs
description: After two EPs and a big single, this young English electronic producer steps out with his debut full-length on Night Slugs, an album that feels more like one long, continuous idea than a series of discrete tracks.

title: Time Team
label: Ninja Tune
description: Offering dubstep filtered through a g-funk lean, the UK producer has never sounded further askew from his generation than on his bold, manic debut LP.

title: Alien Tentacle Sex EP
label: self-released
description: This Toronto R&B singer shares a lot with the Weeknd, including a producer (Illangelo), subject matter, and vibe, in addition to the eerily similar vocal melodies.

title: The Plot Against Common Sense
label: Xtra Mile
description: On his latest for his post-Mclusky band, Andy Falkous still manages to serve up a healthy amount of bile, but some of his targets are questionable.

title: Heaven
label: Fat Possum
description: On their sixth record, a gloriously pretty collection that features guest vocals from Fleet Foxes' Robin Pecknold, the Walkmen have made a bewildered, giddy paean to their own happiness.

title: Body Faucet
label: Vagrant
description: The Athens, Ga., band uses its debut LP as a vat in which to hastily dump the past five years of top-shelf indie into some kind of frat party-stoking jungle juice.

title: A Shut-In's Prayer
label: Caldo Verde
description: Released on Red House Painters/Sun Kil Moon mastermind Mark Kozelek's Caldo Verde label, the debut LP from Owen Ashworth's post-Casiotone for the Painfully Alone project is the most wistful work he's committed to tape.

title: Passage
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On their audacious, ambitious Secretly Canadian debut LP, the Brooklyn duo of Aleksa Palladino and Devon Church show there's a bigger hook to their band than their romantic backstory.

title: Empyrean
label: Prosthetic
description: After some solid EPs, the Brooklyn black metal band's debut LP finds a way to reinvigorate the old-school black metal template with a sound that's stately and epic, but booze-soaked, filthy, and feral.

title: Ram
label: Hear Music
description: Paul McCartney's Ram is a domestic-bliss album, one of the weirdest, earthiest, and most honest ever made. What 2012's ears can find is a rock icon inventing an approach to pop music that would eventually become someone else's indie pop.

title: Silfra
label: Interscope
description: The classical violinist Hilary Hahn holed up in Iceland for two months to record with German pianist and indie classical composer Hauschka. The result is a record about fiddling around happily with music's guts.

title: Music for Neighbors
label: Acute
description: All five current members of the Feelies were involved in this 1980s N.J. band at some point, but the Trypes were more than an offshoot. Acute's reissue collects their sole release, 1984's The Explorers Hold EP, plus demos, live performances, and previously unheard practice sessions.

title: Deep Thuds
label: Richie
description: Jason Killinger of the Philadelphia lo-fi rock'n'roll band Birds of Maya, the group that also birthed Purling Hiss, delivers a compulsively listenable, spaced-out set.

title: Go! Pop! Bang!
label: Interscope
description: On her long-delayed debut, the 21-year-old rapper proves she was ahead of the curve as a young teenager performing in Baltimore, and that M.I.A. was smart to recruit her when she assembled her N.E.E.T. team.

title: Words and Music by Saint Etienne
label: Interscope
description: The English electronic pop band's first proper album since 2005 is a sterling affirmation that relating music to your life doesn't have to grow more difficult as you get older.

title: Rhine Gold
label: Ghostly
description: The Copenhagen group's second album is a hook-laden prog-pop opus that bridges whatever currently falls under the heading of "post rock" with the past five years of flannel-wearing American indie.

title: Unpatterns
label: Wichita
description: The English duo's latest studio album backs away from the darkness of 2010's Delicacies and moves toward the pleasure principle once again.

title: Internal Logic
label: HLR
description: There's evidence all over Grass Widow's third album that the San Francisco post-punk band has spent the two years since its last album tightening its sound. It's an approach that feels more personal and self-contained than it does trendy.

title: Masterpiece
label: Ministry of Sound
description: Based on his most recent London club night, the English DJ/producer's 3xCD contribution to Ministry of Sounds's "Masterpiece" series is a collection of remixes that showcase his idiosyncratic way of forging links between the underground and more populist fare.

title: Clear Moon
label: P.W. Elverum & Sun
description: Phil Elverum recently took an extended break from touring to record two albums in a studio he built in a deconsecrated church. The first of these albums makes a vast, cool sanctuary of itself and quietly beckons you into it.

title: Pinkish Black
label: Handmade Birds
description: Formed after the suicide of the bassist from their previous group, Texas duo Pinkish Black offer a dark blend of death-rock, metal, punk, and synthesized drone on their self-titled debut.

title: Majenta
label: Hotflush
description: The Detroit producer and fashion photographer's first album for Scuba mastermind Paul Rose's Hotflush label might make you want to take a shower.

title: Sunburn EP
label: Greco-Roman
description: The Vampire Weekend bassist's first solo outing feels connected to his playing in his usual band but also extends far from anything on Vampire Weekend's records.

title: Natural History
label: Drag City
description: The Baltimore noise-rock quartet's sophomore album, their first for Drag City, finds them softening their sound but still nailing the sweet spot between savagery and self-awareness.

title: Cancer for Cure
label: Fat Possum
description: Featuring guest spots from Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire, Danny Brown, and a snarling Killer Mike, El-P's first album since putting Def Jux on hiatus in early 2010 marks a break from the old order and another call to arms.

title: Civilization
label: Tectonic
description: The dot-connecting Atlanta bass producer's first album for Tectonic feels like a rapid succession of new-direction singles gathered together as an overarching summary of a growing artist.

title: RØSENKØPF
label: Wierd
description: Drawing from goth and industrial, this promising Brooklyn noise-rock trio creates rhythmic, surprisingly accessible music that hits with brute muscle rather than harsh abrasion.

title: Dreamchasers 2
label: Warner Bros.
description: On the Philly rapper's first mixtape to reflect his heightened profile-- a collection featuring guest spots from Drake, Wale, Big Sean, Fabolous, and Kendrick Lamar, among others-- he doesn't so much step out of his own world as merge it with the one he's about to enter.

title: The Visitors [Deluxe Edition]
label: Polar
description: A fifth reissue of a 30-year old album needs something remarkable to make fans bite, and EMI promised just that for this edition of ABBA's risk-taking final record, which hosts their first piece of unreleased material since 1994, along with a set of uniformly terrific bonus tracks.

title: Ufabulum
label: Warp
description: The English electronic musician's newest is in many ways a return to his earliest material. If people have forgotten the whimsical-yet-punishing pleasures of Squarepusher's breakbeat chaos, might it be a good a place to get onboard?

title: Dismania
label: Hardly Art
description: The N.Y. sludge-punk band, featuring former Black Lips member Jack Hines and Golden Triangle's Vashti Windish, offer buckets of blood and bile on their aggressive sophomore LP.

title: Heavy
label: Innova
description: The visceral N.Y. string quartet's third solo album is a collection of dark thoughts and relentless pressures: Ethel function as a living affront to the misconception that chamber music is polite, white-napkin stuff.

title: A.C.R. 1999
label: Dischord
description: Recorded in a 1999 session, A.C.R. 1999 includes previously unreleased tracks as well as songs that were re-made for the Baltimore post-punk legends' ninth album, Necrophones, heard here in sharper, more muscular form.

title: Bizarre Ride II the Pharcyde: The Singles Collection Music Box
label: Delicious Vinyl
description: This limited singles box for the 1992 debut LP from the L.A. rap group Pharcyde highlights their dizzying mix of SoCal 420 culture, jazzy bohemianism, and self-conscious rap smarts.

title: Not Your Kind of People
label: STUNVOLUME
description: For their first release in seven years, Garbage faced a conundrum similar to that of many artists who found success in the alt-rock 1990s: Do you update your approach to conform to a more contemporary sound, or do you keep partying like it's 1998?

title: Live
label: Innervisions
description: The Carl Craig-nodding German techno duo's first full-length since their 2004 eponymous debut is an 80-minute DJ set that presents a potted history of the group's last eight years.

title: Into the Trees
label: Text
description: The London-via-Chicago psych-folk songwriter's sophomore LP, produced by Four Tet's Kieran Hebden and released on his label, features guest spots from Radiohead's Colin Greenwood.

title: True
label: Slumberland
description: Jorge Elbrecht moved his shape-shifting post-Lansing-Dreiden pop band to Slumberland for their sophomore LP, a collection that incorporates the roar of first-wave shoegazers into the mix.

title: Shot Forth Self Living / The Buried Life
label: Captured Tracks
description: The Los Angeles noise-pop band's early-1990s catalog gets an extensive work-through courtesy of Captured Tracks.

title: The Only Place
label: Mexican Summer
description: Best Coast's Jon Brion-produced second album finds the band leaning toward alt country and working in a more stripped-down mode, with Bethany Cosentino's voice front-and-center.

title: I Feel So Far Away: Anthology 1974-1998
label: Sundazed
description: This 2xCD collection, which draws from four albums and other material the Velvet Underground drummer recorded over two decades, includes guest spots from her VU bandmates as well as Daniel Johnston and members of Half Japanese, the Violent Femmes, and Sonic Youth.

title: V
label: Editions Mego
description: The first album in three years from the international drone-doom duo of Sunn O)))'s Stephen O' Malley and Pita's Peter Rehberg offers a surprising junction of various musical outfields.

title: Köima
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The Malian folk-blues singer recorded his first Thrill Jockey LP in his sister's house in Gao with a string of collaborators, often in one or two takes. His second, Koïma, is a more structured, subtly arranged offering.

title: Neck of the Woods
label: Dangerbird
description: In the age of downloading and streaming, the L.A. alt-rock band still makes albums like it needs to take full advantage of a CD's storage capacity.

title: R.A.P. Music
label: Williams Street
description: On R.A.P. Music, Killer Mike hooks up with El-P and Adult Swim subsidiary Williams Street for the 2012 equivalent to Ice Cube and the Bomb Squad's similarly inspired bicoastal union on AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted.

title: Super Vague EP
label: Fan Death
description: The Baltimore quartet, led by Denny Bowen of the recently defunct post-punk trio Double Dagger, revives the fuzz and feedback-laden churn of early-90s indie rock without so many of the bad vibes.

title: Prophet
label: Barsuk
description: The ex-Menomena multi-instrumentalist returns with his second full-length, and it's another production wonder, vast and symphonic one moment, stark and intimate the next.

title: Motion Sickness of Time Travel
label: Spectrum Spools
description: Though often gentle and reflective, there's a forcefulness to Rachel Evans' drone-based music. Her newest double LP as Motion Sickness of Time Travel is her most definitive statement to date.

title: Fear Fun
label: Sub Pop
description: On his eighth solo LP, his first as Father John Misty, ex-Fleet Foxes drummer Josh Tillman has shaken his lonesome, somber tone in favor of something more gregarious, engaging, even funny.

title: Bloom
label: Sub Pop
description: Two years ago, Teen Dream felt like such a complete realization of Beach House's potential that it had to make you wonder where they could possibly go from there. By just about every measure, the Baltimore duo's fourth album is stronger than anything they've done before.

title: Versions
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Though it came from the same improvised studio session, David Daniell and Tortoise/Eleventh Dream Day player Douglas McCombs' second LP is a marked improvement on their first collaboration.

title: Gallery EP
label: Captured Tracks
description: Justin Vallesteros follows Craft Spells' Idle Labor with an EP of six songs-- essentially makeout music for loners-- that could have easily served as deep cuts on that promising 2011 debut.

title: DROKK: Music Inspired by Mega-City One
label: Invada
description: Started as the soundtrack for Pete Travis' forthcoming Judge Dredd adaptation, Portishead's Geoff Barrow teamed with Emmy-nominated composer Ben Salisbury for this tribute to the fictional setting of the comic book series.

title: Royal Headache
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: This Australian garage-rock band's vocalist is several shades more complex and adaptable than your typical throat-shredding truth-teller: His warm, soulful voice pilots his group's promising 26-minute self-titled debut.

title: Isn't Anything / Loveless / EPs 1988-1991
label: Sony
description: My Bloody Valentine's output during the band's miracle years between 1988 and 1991 still feels like a gift.

title: Family Perfume Vol. 1 / Family Perfume Vol. 2
label: Woodsist
description: White Fence's recent collaboration with Ty Segall sounds hi-fi in comparison to this paisley-tinted pair of fuzzed-out records, which leader Tim Presley pieced together from a year spent crouched over a 4-track.

title: Deathless Master
label: Southern Lord
description: Dropping the crust punk of their earlier offerings, the San Francisco band is committed to old-school death metal on its brutal, surprisingly catchy latest LP.

title: A Different Ship
label: Secretly Canadian
description: Here We Go Magic's latest turns songwriter Luke Temple's anxiety of non-commitment into an aesthetic of sorts, with the results proving strangely medicated.

title: Dopesmoker
label: Southern Lord
description: Almost 20 years after it was recorded and rejected by London Records and then made public as unofficial bootlegs or unagreeable edits, stoner-rock legends Sleep's storied one-song, hour-long third album is finally available through a remastered, re-illustrated reissue.

title: OFF!
label: Vice
description: OFF!'s debut LP, which comes in just shy of First Four EPs' runtime, again finds Keith Morris venting spleen at anything and everything. This time out, though, his targets seem softer and a little harder to pin down.

title: Oh Holy Molar
label: Kranky
description: On the minimalist English chamber-pop band's second album, vocalist/pianist Lucinda Chua filters raw emotion through pith and poetry.

title: Posthuman
label: 3by3
description: Touted as a return to his Godflesh days, Justin K. Broadrick's newest project steps away from Jesu's dreaminess to a dark, brutal electronic realm.

title: The Electronic Anthology Project of Dinosaur Jr.
label: self-released
description: J Mascis and Built to Spill bassist Brett Nelson offer a collection of Dinosaur Jr. synth-pop covers, culled mostly from the band's 1987 SST classic, You're Living All Over Me.

title: Complete Discography
label: Temporary Residence
description: This reissue of the Maryland post-hardcore group Moss Icon's Complete Discograpy is essential because, like Fugazi, Slint, or any other wondrous butterfly nourished in hardcore's cocoon, they were a band that forged their own universe.

title: Galaxy Garden
label: R&S
description: With his fifth album since 2007, dance producer Matt Cutler has released his most complete statement: Each track on Galaxy Garden is a maximalist marvel in minimalist disguise.

title: Memory
label: Monkeytown
description: On its first album for Modeselektor's Monkeytown label, the L.A./Berlin bass duo further develops its tendency to put together one subgenre's tracks by another subgenre's rules.

title: Hoyas EP
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Blending mumbled folk and bleary-eyed blips, the Bon Iver percussionist's new solo EP feels like the soundtrack for an ice-slicked, insomniac winter drive.

title: Death Dreams
label: Paper Bag
description: On its second LP, the Canadian fuzz-rock duo drowns its sorrows with very loud and brash songs about very small and internal breakdowns.

title: Urban Turban
label: Ample Play
description: Three years into a remarkably prolific second phase, Cornershop release a playful 12-song collection that finds them teaming up with an international cast of vocalists.

title: We Rose From Your Bed With the Sun in Our Head
label: Young God
description: Focusing on new material, this live 2xCD collection from Swans' first tour in more than a decade finds the loud, mean, and complicated Michael Gira-led sextet beating past successes with the purpose of the present.

title: Heirlooms
label: Circus Company
description: Taking his late father's jazz trumpet legacy as source material, Marc Barrite's second LP as Dave Aju is a deeply affecting work that channels house, funk and the messages of George Clinton.

title: Half Blood
label: Relapse
description: Frostbitten Scandinavian black metal and rustic U.S. roots music harmonize on Horseback's second proper LP to create a sweeping mix of ugliness and beauty. It's post-rock at its most spartan and hard rock at its most out-there.

title: In the Belly of the Brazen Bull
label: Wichita
description: The UK band's Dave Fridmann- and Steve Albini-produced fifth album goes full-blown 1990s Buzz Bin. Fortunately, the Cribs write better hooks than C-level revivalists.

title: Club Rez EP
label: Night Slugs
description: Almost two years after the release of the astonishing single "Wut", the UK producer is back with a new EP for Night Slugs: Can he make lightning strike twice?

title: Dr Dee
label: Parlophone
description: A departure from his recent work with Gorillaz and Rocket Juice & the Moon, Dr Dee is the stately, melancholy soundtrack to the opera Damon Albarn wrote for director Rufus Norris.

title: The Diver
label: Sacred Bones
description: On their second album, and Sacred Bones debut, the Wierd-affiliated N.Y. band is obsessed with wringing genuine emotion from decrepit electronics.

title: Electra Heart
label: Atlantic
description: Marina Lambrini Diamandis' second album is a high-gloss record made with Dr. Luke, Stargate, Greg Kurstin, and Liam Howe, and dressed in layers of philosophy, mythology, and blonde wigs.

title: The LHI Years: Nudes, Singles & Backsides (1968-1971)
label: Light in the Attic
description: This set from the late singer-songwriter and producer collects tracks cut for his own LHI label. His biggest hits as a songwriter were behind him, but Hazlewood still had plenty of weirdo ambition.

title: Mondo
label: Downtown
description: The buzzed-about L.A. band's Danger Mouse-produced debut is a cautionary tale of what happens when a "hit record" forgets to actually include hits.

title: Hair
label: Drag City
description: Garage-rock wunderkind Ty Segall's collaborative album with Tim Presley of White Fence is an absorbing maze of detours. They're the sort of people who seemingly enjoy pulling support beams out of songs to see how they hop along without them.

title: Damned
label: Southern Lord
description: Four years after their last release, the Swedish crust punks Wolfbrigade return with a vicious Southern Lord debut and, one may hope, a new lease on life.

title: Loot
label: Muti Music
description: Political in the non-dogmatic way of someone open to new experiences in a world hostile to difference, the Barcelona-via-Los Angeles producer's third LP presents a vision of global bass culture that goes down smoothly without blanding.

title: Live in Detroit 1986
label: Knitting Factory
description: The Nigerian Afrobeat pioneer performed this hypnotic, four-song, two-and-a-half-hour set less than a year after being released from prison, and his pointed, usually funny monologues about that wrongful imprisonment are a large part of this 3xCD collection's charm.

title: Exercises EP
label: Paper Bag
description: With this chilly, quietly compelling EP of piano ruminations, Montreal producer Mike Silver unveils his most intriguing material to date.

title: World, You Need a Change of Mind
label: Polydor
description: On his debut Kindness LP, the buzzy UK songwriter Adam Bainbridge offers washed-out new wave, strobing disco, lite funk, atmospheric balladry, and a couple unexpected covers.

title: Echoes and Rhymes
label: Elefant
description: The UK indie pop band's first LP in 21 years is a collection of covers of 196os obscurities, but Echoes & Rhymes is more than a curio.

title: Art Dealer Chic, Vols. 1-3
label: self-released
description: Armed with a diverse bag of tricks, the 25-year-old L.A. singer offers some of the best R&B of the year on these three fearless EPs.

title: Strange Land
label: Barsuk
description: Yellow Ostrich's first album as a trio opens up Alex Schaaf's bedroom-pop sound: He's a lonely soul, but on Strange Land, he's in good company.

title: Aufheben
label: A
description: Recorded in East Berlin with a cast of session musicians and a couple of longtime collaborators, Aufheben is Anton Newcombe's most consistent, sonically lustrous album in years.

title: Master of My Make-Believe
label: Atlantic
description: Four years after her genre-blending debut, Santigold offers a polished assortment of global pop tunes produced by the likes of Q-Tip, TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek, Boys Noize, and Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner.

title: The Ghost in Daylight
label: Warp
description: Continuing to explore themes of "compulsion, degradation, and the possibility of transcendence," the Bristol musician's first LP since 2007 adds an icy despair to his earlier folk-oriented releases.

title: I Predict a Graceful Expulsion
label: Mute
description: The 24-year old Canadian singer's transfixing voice brings warmth to her chilly debut, a collection that subtly tugs against the big, major-network-drama payoff for which it feels custom-built.

title: Black Is Beautiful
label: Hyperdub
description: The debut Hyperdub LP from the duo once known as Hype Williams feels like a trip through the fragments of their collective psyches.

title: Blow Away Your Troubles / On Any Normal Monday / Midnight Cleaners
label: Captured Tracks
description: Cleaners From Venus, the lo-fi pop project of the English musician Martin Newell, offered a mix of rough edges, distanced vocals, definite hooks, and unexpected mixing choices. This box set features the first three 1980s cassette-only efforts with liner notes, flyers, buttons, and unreleased tracks and photos.

title: Nootropics
label: Ribbon Music
description: Incorporating synths, ambient drift, and stark percussion, the Baltimore band, fronted by onetime folk eccentric Jana Hunter, widens its sonic palette and scope on this richly detailed sophomore LP.

title: Concatenating Fields
label: Bark and Hiss
description: The Akron, Ohio, husband-and-wife duo's newest, an album of "nighttime grass thoughts," finds ambient sounds and loops coexist quietly together.

title: Dark York
label: Greedhead
description: The NYC queer rapper Khalif Diouf's dark, sleek debut mixtape, featuring production work from Nguzunguzu, feels animated by the force of its own movement.

title: Light Asylum
label: Mexican Summer
description: The Brooklyn electro-goth duo of Shannon Funchess and Bruno Coviello has personality and style to spare, but is that enough to carry this full-length debut?

title: Meantime EP
label: Warp
description: The London producer's new EP is an unabashedly beautiful, even sensuous 17 minutes of music: He's a startlingly clear new voice, and here, he's just clearing his throat.

title: Fevers and Mirrors / There Is No Beginning to the Story EP
label: Saddle Creek
description: A dozen years after its release, Fevers & Mirrors, Bright Eyes' defining LP, is reissued by Saddle Creek, along with 2002's There Is No Beginning to the Story EP.

title: Mohn
label: Kompakt
description: The lastest collaboration by German techno heroes Wolfgang Voigt and Jorg Burger is essentially an ambient record, though it manages to avoid the sterility of actual background music.

title: First of My Kind EP
label: Columbia
description: The young Paul Weller- and Oasis-approved Liverpudlian, who records as one half of the Last Shadow Puppets with Arctic Monkeys' Alex Turner, offers a four-song EP.

title: Pluto
label: Epic
description: On his debut album, the Atlanta rapper/singer makes his strongest case yet that he is one of the foremost sources of rap that's as peculiar as it is pop. He also miraculously shows that it's still possible for Auto-Tune to be an interesting artistic tool.

label: Greedhead
description: Recorded in Oakland with a heavy presence of Bay Area producers and rappers, the Das Racist member's highly listenable second mixtape of 2012 is a testament to his heretofore untested malleability.

title: Mermaid Avenue: The Complete Sessions
label: Nonesuch
description: All three installments of Wilco and Billy Bragg's tribute to Woody Guthrie are collected in this compilation, which lovingly-- and in timely fashion-- shows there was more to the Okie folkie than protest music.

title: Valot Kaukaa
label: Preservation
description: Finnish producer Olli Aarni explores the boundaries between repetition and the unpredictable, analog and digital, clarity and warble. His new album makes a strong argument for distortion as a reverie-inducing narcotic.

title: Seven Bells
label: Prophecy
description: On their Tom G. Warrior-mixed fifth album, the German black-metal band Secrets of the Moon have defrosted their Satanic hymns and amped up the swagger.

title: Poor Moon
label: Tompkins Square
description: Initially out last year on a small vinyl-only edition, this collection of skewed country-soul greatness deserves to be heard by more ears.

title: You Know You Like It EP
label: Tri Angle
description: The London duo's debut EP is a full-bodied, slinky embrace of the weirder end of R&B trailblazed by Timbaland and the Neptunes a decade ago.

title: R.I.P.
label: Honest Jon's
description: Darren Cunningham is a dance producer who references extroverted, populist music to create a meditative, introverted, immersive experience.

title: Lifetime of Romance
label: Not Not Fun
description: With his latest, the young Bloomington, Ind., electronic artist moves on from the abstract sonic adventures of his earlier work to a collection of unabashed synth pop.

title: Cynic's New Year
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: For Horse Feathers' latest album, Justin Ringle brought in scores of Portland musicians to add flourishes of piano, reeds, banjo, and horns. He's expanding his band's palette, not necessarily its sound.

title: Sentenced to Life
label: Southern Lord
description: The Seattle death- and thrash-influenced quintet draws members from Shook Ones, Go It Alone, Blue Monday, and Get the Most, and their second Southern Lord LP is proudly in the hardcore tradition.

title: Ugly
label: Don Giovanni
description: The fifth disc from the New Brunswick, N.J., punk trio builds off the group's reputation as shred-oriented SST revivalists, with a refined focus on songwriting.

title: All Hell
label: White Denim
description: The onetime trucker and drummer of the stoner metal band Pearls and Brass releases a solo album that finds him crooning, beautifully, over country-music samples.

title: Golden Rhythm/Ink Music
label: Rune Grammofon
description: Showcasing a knack for marrying the absurd to the sublime, the eccentric English band offers its first album in five years.

title: True Predation
label: Translation Loss
description: This Columbus, Ohio, quartet finds a way to infuse familiar punk templates with subtle progressive elements, resulting in an album that feels like a thick swamp of crust, muck, piss, and bile.

title: What Kind of World
label: Readymade
description: The Raconteurs member's fifth solo album finds him playing the rock'n'roll loser once again, and occasionally meriting the Alex Chilton haircut he sports on its cover.

title: June 2009
label: Carpark
description: Chaz Bundick reached into his archives for this collection of singles written around the time of his debut, Causers of This. It allows you to think "big picture" not only about Bundick, but the role of production and atmosphere in general.

title: The Money Store
label: Epic
description: Death Grips are angry. It's unclear why. But on their major label debut, the Sacramento noise group's monomaniacal desire to rain down fiery destruction on the powers-that-be is crystal-clear, even if nothing else is.

title: Da Mind of Traxman
label: Planet Mu
description: The veteran Chicago producer's Planet Mu debut is an album more concerned with footwork's past than its future: it's a loving musical history set on loop.

title: This Machine
label: The End
description: Given its promising start, you might be inclined to place the Dandy Warhols' ninth LP on the level of the alt-rock band's first three records. But then it keeps going.

title: Candy Salad
label: Frenchkiss
description: On their sophomore album, the Yeasayer and MGMT-associated Brooklyn chamber-pop band leave every sound tweaked or otherwise troubled.

title: Harmonicraft
label: Volcom
description: The Miami sludge-pop band's third album feels like an attempt to make a break with the past, but they might not be able to, at least not yet.

title: Blunderbuss
label: Columbia
description: Following the dissolution of the White Stripes and his marriage to model/singer Karen Elson, Jack White releases his first solo LP. Rife with songs about fear and loss, Blunderbuss feels unusually personal.

title: Diamond Rugs
label: Partisan
description: Deer Tick's John McCauley and Robbie Crowell and members of the Black Lips, Dead Confederate, Los Lobos, and Six Finger Satellite kick up dust on Diamond Rugs' self-titled debut.

title: Love Is the Plan, the Plan Is Death
label: Important
description: The gifted 12-string guitarist's latest album-- featuring guest vocals from Geneviève Beaulieu of drone/black metal outfit Menace Ruine-- is a continuation of his tinkering with a variety of instruments as well as a return to his past solo work.

title: Everything EP
label: Well Rounded
description: Following a string of interesting genre detours, Manchester producer Rupert Taylor's house-centric new EP is his most consistently pleasurable release to date.

title: Blackwater Park [Legacy Edition] / Deliverance [Reissue] / Damnation [Reissue] / Lamentations [Reissue]
label: The End
description: The Swedish band, which mixes psychedelia, prog, and extreme metal, reissues three ambitious studio albums and a live DVD from the early years of the millennium, records that found it transitioning from death growls to cleanly sung acoustic compositions.

title: The Flaming Lips and Heady Fwends
label: Warner Bros.
description: This Record Store Day round-up of collaborations conducted over the past year features a cast that includes Ke$ha, Chris Martin, Nick Cave, Yoko Ono, Bon Iver, Neon Indian, and Lightning Bolt, among others. Amazingly, it hangs together well as a front-to-back album.

title: Woods / Amps for Christ
label: Shrimper
description: This split release sees Amps for Christ's Henry Barnes in as messy a mood as ever, with his taste for roughness rubbing off on Woods' rustic offerings.

title: Netherwards
label: Dark Descent
description: The Seattle death/doom band's bleakly elegant debut album is powerful, complex, and overwhelmingly dense.

title: 2 RMX
label: Anti-
description: Grinderman's final release is a collection of remixes by Yeah Yeah Yeahs' Nick Zinner, Factory Floor, QOTSA's Josh Homme, UNKLE, and Robert Fripp, among others.

title: Savage Journey to the American Dream
label: Maybach
description: Rick Ross' latest protégé does his thing over a collection of impeccable beats, courtesy of the Neptunes' Chad Hugo and Block Beattaz, among others.

title: Essential Mix
label: BBC
description: The manic, unclassifiable Glasgow producer's overstuffed, expertly curated contribution to the BBC's Essential Mix program pulls together threads from across the musical spectrum.

title: Brass Tactics EP
label: Good to Die
description: This Bellingham math-punk trio's riotously complex three-song EP is the mark of an exhilarating new voice that's fun, ferocious, and exhausting in the most satisfying kind of way.

title: Lissy Trullie
label: Downtown
description: The John Hill (Santigold, M.I.A.) and David Sitek-produced follow-up to 2009's Self-Taught Learner EP arrives fashionably late, and clad in halfway-convincing post-punk attire.

title: The Block Brochure: Welcome to the Soil 1, 2, & 3
label: Heavy on the Grind
description: Not everything works on the Bay Area rapper's sprawling three-volume, 60-track offering, but not only are none of these songs bad, two-thirds of them range from good to mind-blowing.

title: Out of the Game
label: Polydor
description: Rufus Wainwright's Mark Ronson-produced seventh album represents the singer's return to more formal song structure, but it also marks a break from the florid, operatic pop that defined his first five albums.

title: Icon Give Thank
label: Rvng Intl.
description: For the most rewarding installment in RVNG's FRKWYS series, Sun Araw and M. Geddes Gengras traveled to Jamaica to collaborate with legendary reggae vocal group the Congos on this psychedelic gospel album.

title: In Between
label: Kanine
description: No longer smothered in fuzz, the San Franciscan shoegazers' second album makes up for what its predecessor lacked in hooks and vocal distinction.

title: History
label: Dark Skies Association
description: The Swedish-born, Berlin-based John Maus collaborator's fourth full-length is a collection of power ballads and off-kilter dance-pop, carried by her commanding, almost Nico-like voice.

title: Europe
label: Slumberland
description: Improving on its promising debut, the London-via-Australia indie pop band offers a bolder, more lyrically and instrumentally beguiling second album.

title: Sees the Light
label: Hardly Art
description: This second, much improved La Sera collection finds Katy Goodman translating what she brings to Vivian Girls into top-shelf songwriting.

title: Dross Glop
label: Warp
description: With contributions from Hudson Mohawke, Kode9, the Field, Gang Gang Dance's Brian Degraw, and Eye from the Boredoms, this varied remix set plays up the humorous and party-starting aspect of Battles' personality.

title: Plateau Vision
label: Western Vinyl
description: Having come to the fore via mash-ups back in the mid-2000s, Raj Haldar continues to investigate contrasts between disparate genres on this original release.

title: Consignment: Favor For a Favor, the Redi-Rock Mixtape
label: self-released
description: The Detroit rapper's subtle poetic gifts and unflinching descriptions of the drug dealer's day-to-day make for a consistent, confident 26-track second album.

title: Spring EP
label: Liberation Technologies
description: Working under a new name for a new label, producer and songwriter Laurel Halo crafts a rich EP that touches on many sounds but manages to feel whole.

title: With Siinai: Heartbreaking Bravery
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Continuing his recent forays into more literal storytelling, Spencer Krug's collaboration with Finnish prog-rockers Siinai is a swirly, molten rumination on heartbreak.

title: Sweet Heart Sweet Light
label: Fat Possum
description: Spiritualized's best album since the defining 1997 monument Ladies and Gentlemen We Are Floating in Space is not so much a drastic transformation as much as an acute refinement, and it also happens to be the most uplifting album of Jason Pierce's career.

title: 120 Days II
label: Splendour
description: The Norwegian electro-rockers' first album in six years focuses on larger-than-life electronics, relegating the guitar to a more supportive role.

title: Armor On EP
label: Our Dawn
description: Free of Diddy's Dirty Money project, the vocalist releases a remarkable EP that eschews traditional R&B, contrasting human sympathies with harsh mechanical sounds.

title: Violet Replacement
label: Yellowelectric
description: Violet Replacement, a 2xCD-R Liz Harris released to support a Grouper tour of the same name, features extended ambient recordings with few vocals.

title: Ruin 3
label: Acéphale
description: The conceptually minded Minneapolis electronic duo invited six artists to remix three of its tracks, contributing to an ongoing project that feels outward-looking and communal.

title: Mr. Impossible
label: Ribbon Music
description: There's an infectious sense of discovery in Black Dice's latest album as the Brooklyn band finds ways to make bizarre music into something tightly structured and fun.

title: Time Capsules II
label: Glassnote
description: Brad Oberhofer and co.'s Steve Lillywhite-produced debut finds a once-modest indie band swinging for the fences in hopes of cracking the big leagues.

title: Monnos
label: Burning World
description: The British doom trio locates the perfect guitar tone on its crushing new LP.

title: Accelerando
label: ACT Music + Vision
description: Pianist Vijay Iyer returns to the trio format for a collaboration with Stephan Crump and Marcus Gilmore that includes jazz interpretations of Michael Jackson, Duke Ellington, and Flying Lotus.

title: Back From the Dead
label: Unknown
description: Chief Keef's breakthrough mixtape, is loud, rough, and unrelenting, but the 16-year-old Chicago rapper's calm, dead-eyed delivery is its most unsettling and intriguing element.

title: MTV Unplugged
label: Island
description: It's hard to imagine a voice more equipped to puff new life into "MTV Unplugged" than Florence Welch's, but the series' stripped-back approach doesn't do her any favors.

title: No1 2 Look Up 2
label: Greedhead
description: The 21-year old Queens MC's first release for the label run by Das Racist's Heems works best when he drops the implausible pose as a hip-hop savior and raps as himself.
